description: b'Madison Buffalo Jump State Park is a Montana state park located seven miles south of the Interstate 90 interchange at Logan in Gallatin County, Montana in the United States. The park preserves a canyon cliff used by Native Americans as a buffalo jump, where herds of bison were stampeded over the cliff as an efficient means of slaughter.[4] The main geographic features of the jump site remain largely unchanged since the days of the jumps. Archaeologists have found tons of bison bones buried at the base of the cliffs. They have also uncovered the remains of tipi villages.[5]'

name: Makoshika State Park
description: b'Makoshika State Park ("ma-KO-sh(ih)kuh" from the Lakota Maco sica, meaning \'bad land\' or \'land of bad spirits\')[2] is a nature preserve  and public recreation area located on the southeast side of Glendive in Dawson County, Montana. The state park encompasses badlands containing dinosaur fossils and rock from the Hell Creek Formation.[2] It is the largest of Montana\'s state parks at more than 11,000 acres (45\xc2\xa0km\xc2\xb2).[4]'

name: Medicine Rocks State Park
description: b'Medicine Rocks State Park is a park owned by the state of Montana in the United States. It is located about 25 miles (40\xc2\xa0km) west-southwest of Baker, Montana, and 11 miles (18\xc2\xa0km) north of Ekalaka, Montana. The park is named for the "Medicine Rocks," a series of sandstone pillars similar to hoodoos some 60 to 80 feet (18 to 24\xc2\xa0m) high with eerie undulations, holes, and tunnels in them.[3][4] The rocks contain numerous examples of Native American rock art,[5] and are considered a sacred holy place by Plains Indians.[6] The park is 330 acres (130\xc2\xa0ha) in size and 3,379 feet (1,030\xc2\xa0m) in elevation.[1] It is managed by the Montana Department of Fish, Wildlife and Parks. Theodore Roosevelt said Medicine Rocks was "as fantastically beautiful a place as I have ever seen".[7]  The park was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2017.[8]'

name: Missouri Headwaters State Park
description: b'Missouri Headwaters State Park is a Montana state park that marks the official start of the Missouri River.  It includes the Three Forks of the Missouri National Historic Landmark, designated in 1960 because the site is one where the Lewis and Clark Expedition camped in 1805.  The park is open for day use and camping, offering hiking trails, hunting, and water-related activities.  It is located on Trident Road northeast of Three Forks, Montana at an elevation of 4,045 feet (1,233\xc2\xa0m).'

name: Painted Rocks State Park
description: b'Painted Rocks State Park is a public recreation area located at the southern end Painted Rocks Reservoir, 24 miles (39\xc2\xa0km) south of Darby, Montana. The state park received its name from the green, yellow and orange lichens which cover the grey and black rock walls of the granite and rhyolite cliffs.[2]'

name: Pictograph Cave (Billings, Montana)
description: b'Pictograph Cave is an area of three caves (Pictograph, Middle, and Ghost caves) located 5 miles (8.0\xc2\xa0km) south of Billings, Montana, United States, preserved and protected in the 23-acre (9.3\xc2\xa0ha) Pictograph Cave State Park.[3]'

name: Pirogue Island State Park
description: b'Pirogue Island State Park is a public recreation area on the Yellowstone River, two miles north of Miles City, Montana. The 269-acre (109\xc2\xa0ha) state park has 2.8 miles (4.5\xc2\xa0km) of designated hiking trails on an island in the river.[2]'

name: Placid Lake State Park
description: b"Placid Lake State Park is a public recreation area located 28 miles (45\xc2\xa0km) northeast of Missoula, Montana. The state park sits on 31 acres (13\xc2\xa0ha) at the eastern end of Placid Lake that include the lake's outlet to Owl Creek, a tributary of the Clearwater River. The park is known for its scenery, camping, aquatic recreation, and fishing.[1]"

name: Rosebud Battlefield State Park
description: b"Rosebud Battlefield State Park in Big Horn County, Montana preserves a large portion of the battlefield of the Battle of the Rosebud, fought on June 17, 1876.  The battle is known by various other names such as The Battle Where the Girl Saved Her Brother by the Northern Cheyenne, and Crook's Fight on the Rosebud.  A National Historic Landmark, the park is a day use facility offering hiking, hunting, picnicking and wildlife viewing.  It is located 11 miles (18\xc2\xa0km) south of Kirby, Montana on Montana Highway 314.[1][3]"

name: Salmon Lake State Park
description: b'Salmon Lake State Park is a public recreation area located approximately 32 miles (51\xc2\xa0km) northeast of Missoula, Montana. The state park occupies 42 acres (17\xc2\xa0ha) on the eastern side of Salmon Lake in the Clearwater River chain between the Mission and Swan mountain ranges.[2]'

name: Sluice Boxes State Park
description: b"Sluice Boxes State Park is a public recreation area in the Little Belt Mountains of Montana, United States, located twelve miles (19\xc2\xa0km) south of Belt on the Kings Hill Scenic Byway.[4] The state park is highlighted by large cliffs and ledges where the northernmost eight miles of the Belt Creek canyon winds out of the Little Belt Mountains. Remains of the area's mining and railroading days are found throughout the canyon. The park offers hiking, floating, picnicking, and backcountry camping.[5]"

name: Smith River State Recreational Waterway
description: b'Smith River State Recreational Waterway, popularly known as the Smith River State Park, is a protected river corridor and "virtual park" owned and operated by the state of Montana in the United States. The site is not officially a state park, but rather a State Recreational Waterway and managed River Corridor. The park consists of the state-owned Smith River; a Montana Department of Fish, Wildlife and Parks (FWP) put-in access point, Camp Baker; 27 FWP-owned and -leased boat camps on the shore of the river; and the FWP-owned Eden Bridge take-out point. Little of the area is owned by FWP. Much of the surrounding shoreline is owned by the United States Forest Service, United States Bureau of Land Management, and private owners. Through management agreements with other government agencies and private landowners, FWP manages the 58.9-mile (94.8\xc2\xa0km) Smith River Corridor as a "virtual state park". The Smith River is the only river in the state of Montana where a permit is required to boat or float on the river.'

name: Spring Meadow Lake State Park
description: b'Spring Meadow Lake State Park is a public recreation area covering 61 acres (25\xc2\xa0ha) just west of Helena, Montana. Once the site of a gravel pit and factory, the state park centers around a man-made, spring-fed lake,[4] which is used for swimming, fishing, non-motorized boating, and scuba diving.[5] The park also offers picnicking, a mile-long trail around the lake, and ice fishing and ice skating in winter.[6] Largemouth bass, westslope cutthroat trout, yellow perch, and pumpkinseed are the main catches.[7] A fishing pier was added to 30-acre (12\xc2\xa0ha) lake in 2011.[8]'

name: Thompson Falls State Park
description: b"Thompson Falls State Park is a public recreation area occupying 36 acres (15\xc2\xa0ha) on the banks of the Clark Fork River, two miles northwest of Thompson Falls, Montana. The state park features a boat launch, children's fishing pond, and riverside trail with mature pine forests surrounding 17 campsites, a group use area, picnicking facilities, birdwatching, and nature walks.[2][4][5]"

name: Tongue River Reservoir State Park
description: b'Tongue River Reservoir State Park is a public recreation area located 6 miles north of Decker, Montana, on the western shore of the Tongue River Reservoir. The 12-mile-long reservoir is an impoundment of the Tongue River. The state park, occupying 642 acres at an elevation of 3468 feet, offers boating, fishing, camping, swimming, wildlife viewing, and a seasonal marina.[1]'

name: Traveler's Rest (Lolo, Montana)
description: b'Traveler\'s Rest was a stopping point of the Lewis and Clark Expedition, located about one mile south of Lolo, Montana. The expedition stopped from September 9 to September 11, 1805, before crossing the Bitterroot Mountains, and again on the return trip from June 30 to July 3, 1806. Traveler\'s Rest is at the eastern end of the Lolo Trail.[5] It was declared a National Historic Landmark in 1960 and added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1966.[3][6] The boundaries were subsequently revised, and mostly lie within the 51-acre (21\xc2\xa0ha) Traveler\'s Rest State Park, which is operated by the Montana Fish, Wildlife & Parks. Significant archeological findings made in 2002, including latrine sites with traces of mercury and fire hearths, make this the only site on the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail that has yielded physical proof of the explorers\' presence.[7] Records made by Lewis and Clark often spell "Traveler\'s" as "Traveller\'s".[6] This spot is largely unchanged from the days of Lewis and Clark.[5] From this location, Lewis and Clark split up to explore Montana during their return trip, not reuniting until they reached Sanish, North Dakota.[8]'

name: Wayfarers State Park
description: b'Wayfarers State Park is a 67-acre (27\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area  overlooking Flathead Lake, one-half mile south of Bigfork, Montana.[4] The state park hosts the annual Northern Rockies Paddlefest at Wayfarers State Park, which in 2013 attracted over 200 participants.[5] In 2016, nearly 160,000 individuals visited the park.[3]'

name: West Shore State Park
description: b'West Shore State Park is a public recreation area occupying 129 acres on the western shore of Flathead Lake five miles south of Lakeside in Lake County, Montana. The state park offers boating, fishing, camping, swimming, hiking, and wildlife viewing.[2]'

name: Whitefish Lake State Park
description: b'Whitefish Lake State Park is a 10-acre (4.0\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area on Whitefish Lake off of U.S. Highway 93, two miles northwest of Whitefish, Montana. It offers boating, swimming, tent and RV camping, and fishing.[2][4] Sites for hike-in and bike-in camping were added in 2016.[5]'

name: Wild Horse Island
description: b'Wild Horse Island is the largest island on Flathead Lake, the largest freshwater lake in Montana.[3] For centuries, the Salish-Kootenai used the island, approximately 2,164 acres (876\xc2\xa0ha) in size,[1][4] in order to pasture horses and keep them from being stolen by other tribes. The island was part of the Flathead Indian Reservation from the time of its creation in 1872 up until its dismantlement in 1904, when the island was divided into individual plots of land. A number of attempts were made on the island towards agricultural development, but none succeeded.[5]'

name: Yellow Bay State Park
description: b'Yellow Bay State Park is a public recreation area occupying fifteen acres (6.1\xc2\xa0ha) on the eastern shore of Flathead Lake twelve miles (19\xc2\xa0km) south of Bigfork in Lake County, Montana. The state park offers boating, fishing, camping, swimming, and wildlife viewing.[2]'

name: Chadron State Park
description: b"Chadron State Park is a public recreation area located within the Nebraska National Forest, nine miles (14\xc2\xa0km) south of Chadron, Nebraska, in the northwestern portion of the state.[3] The park's 974 acres (394\xc2\xa0ha) include a portion of the Pine Ridge escarpment and Chadron Creek. The park is wooded with ponderosa pine throughout and cottonwood trees near the creek and lagoon."

name: Eugene T. Mahoney State Park
description: b'Denzel Mahoney State Park is a public recreation area located on the Platte River, off Interstate 80, approximately four miles (6.4\xc2\xa0km) east of Ashland, Nebraska. The state park features lodging and conferencing facilities, an aquatic center, marina, multi-purpose trails, the Kountze Memorial Theater, multiple facilities for event rentals, and a 70-foot (21\xc2\xa0m) observation tower overlooking the Platte River Valley.[5]'

name: Fort Robinson
description: b'Fort Robinson is a former U.S. Army fort and now a major feature of Fort Robinson State Park, a 22,000-acre (8,900\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation and historic preservation area located 2 miles (3.2\xc2\xa0km) west of Crawford on U.S. Route 20 in the Pine Ridge region of northwest Nebraska.'

name: Indian Cave State Park
description: b'Indian Cave State Park is a public recreation and historic preservation area covering nearly 3,400 acres (1,400\xc2\xa0ha) along the Missouri River in southeast Nebraska. The state park preserves a cave with prehistoric petroglyphs as well as the partially reconstructed village of St. Deroin established in 1853 as part of the former Nemaha Half-Breed Reservation.[4] The state park lies ten miles (16\xc2\xa0km) south of Brownville and eight miles (13\xc2\xa0km) east of Shubert, straddling the county line between Nemaha and Richardson counties.[5]'

name: Niobrara State Park
description: b'Niobrara State Park is a public recreation area located at the confluence of the Missouri and Niobrara rivers in the northeast corner of Nebraska.[5] The state park occupies river bluffs to the west of the village of Niobrara and the Niobrara River. The park includes the Niobrara River Bridge, a decommissioned railroad bridge listed on the National Register of Historic Places.[6] A variety of animals, notably  white-tailed deer and wild turkeys, roam the park by day, while at night, coyotes and whip-poor-wills mingle their cries and calls.[7] The park is managed by the Nebraska Game and Parks Commission.'

name: Platte River State Park
description: b'Platte River State Park is a public recreation area encompassing 453 acres (183\xc2\xa0ha) on the southern bluffs of the Platte River two miles (3.2\xc2\xa0km) west of Louisville, Nebraska. The state park has a relatively steep, rolling topography compared to the surrounding region, with much of it forested.[3]'

name: Ponca State Park
description: b"Ponca State Park is a public recreation area located on the banks of the Missouri River four miles (6.4\xc2\xa0km) north of Ponca, Nebraska, in the northeastern corner of the state. The state park's approximately 2,100 acres (850\xc2\xa0ha) are situated among high bluffs and steep, forested hills adjacent to the Missouri National Recreational River. The park is managed by the Nebraska Game and Parks Commission.[3]"

name: Smith Falls
description: b'Smith Falls, at 63 feet (19 m), is the highest waterfall in the state of Nebraska and the centerpiece of Smith Falls State Park. The state park and falls are located 12 miles (19\xc2\xa0km) east-north east of Valentine and 3 miles south west of Sparks, on the south side of the Niobrara River. Access to the falls is via a footbridge across the river from the north side of the park.[5]'

name: Arbor Lodge State Historical Park and Arboretum
description: b'Arbor Lodge State Historical Park and Arboretum is a mansion and arboretum located at 2600 Arbor Avenue, Nebraska City, Nebraska, United States.[5] The park is a National Historic Landmark listed on the National Register of Historic Places since 1969.[3]'

name: Ash Hollow State Historical Park
description: b'Ash Hollow State Historical Park is located five miles (8.0\xc2\xa0km) south of Lewellen in Garden County, Nebraska. The park comprises two attractions located 2.5 miles (4.0\xc2\xa0km) from each other: Ash Hollow Cave and Windlass Hill.[5]'

name: Ashfall Fossil Beds
description: b'The Ashfall Fossil Beds of Antelope County in northeastern Nebraska are rare fossil sites of the type called lagerst\xc3\xa4tten that, due to extraordinary local conditions, capture a moment in time ecological "snapshot" in a range of well-preserved fossilized organisms. Ash from a Yellowstone hotspot eruption 10-12 million years ago created these fossilized bone beds.'

name: Bowring Ranch State Historical Park
description: b'Bowring Ranch State Historical Park is a state park of Nebraska, USA, interpreting the ranching heritage of the Sand Hills region and the lives of former owners Arthur and Eva Bowring (the first female U.S. Senator from Nebraska). The park is three miles (4.8\xc2\xa0km) north of Merriman in Cherry County, near the South Dakota border.'

name: Buffalo Bill Ranch
description: b"Buffalo Bill Ranch State Historical Park, known as Scout's Rest Ranch, is a living history state park located west of North Platte, Nebraska. The ranch was established in 1878 with an initial purchase of 160 acres south of the Union Pacific tracks by William (Buffalo Bill) Cody. The 4,000 acre ranch was sold in 1911 and has been under the management of the Nebraska Game and Parks Commission since 1964. The 25 acre historic state park, added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1978 and designated a National Historic Landmark in 2021, is open weekdays from April to October. The house and outbuildings can be toured, including a museum documenting Cody's life from a Pony Express rider to his Wild West shows."

name: Fort Hartsuff State Historical Park
description: b'Fort Hartsuff State Historical Park is a state park located six miles (9.7\xc2\xa0km) southeast of Burwell, Nebraska, preserving a typical U.S. Army cavalry outpost of the late 19th century. Fort Hartsuff was active from 1874 to 1881. Among its surviving original structures are the post headquarters, enlisted men\xe2\x80\x99s barracks, officers\xe2\x80\x99 quarters, commanding officers quarters, and post hospital; other buildings have been reconstructed.[3]'

name: Fort Kearny
description: b'Fort Kearny was a historic outpost of the United States Army founded in 1848 in the western U.S. during the middle and late 19th century. The fort was named after Col. and later General Stephen Watts Kearny.[1]  The outpost was located along the Oregon Trail near Kearney, Nebraska.  The town of Kearney took its name from the fort.  The "e" was added to Kearny by postmen who consistently misspelled the town name.[2] A portion of the original site is preserved as Fort Kearny State Historical Park by the Nebraska Game and Parks Commission.[3]'

name: Rock Creek Station
description: b'Rock Creek Station was a stagecoach and Pony Express station in southeastern Nebraska, three miles northeast of the present-day village of Endicott. The site is preserved as Rock Creek Station State Historical Park.[3]'

name: Bluewater Lake State Park
description: b'Bluewater Lake State Park is a state park in Prewitt, New Mexico, United States, located in the Zuni Mountains 30 miles (48\xc2\xa0km) west of Grants.[2] The park itself encompasses approximately 3,000 acres (12\xc2\xa0km2), and the lake has a surface area of approximately 1,200 acres (4.9\xc2\xa0km2).'

name: Bottomless Lakes State Park
description: b'Bottomless Lakes State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of New Mexico, located along the Pecos River, about 15 miles (24\xc2\xa0km) southeast of Roswell. Established in 1933, it was the first state park in New Mexico.[2]  It takes its name from nine small, deep lakes located along the eastern escarpment of the Pecos River valley.  The escarpment is an ancient limestone reef, similar to the limestone mountains around Carlsbad Caverns, 80 miles (130\xc2\xa0km) to the south. Caves formed within the limestone, and as the Pecos River eroded the escarpment, the caves eventually collapsed, leaving behind several deep, almost circular lakes known as cenotes.[3]'

name: Brantley Lake State Park
description: b'Brantley Lake State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located approximately 12 miles (19\xc2\xa0km) north of Carlsbad.[2]  The park takes its name from Brantley Lake, a man-made reservoir created when Brantley Dam was built across the Pecos River in the 1980s. The lake is the southernmost lake in New Mexico, and it is popular for boating and fishing. It has a surface area of approximately 4,000 acres (16\xc2\xa0km2), but that varies due to the inconsistent flow of the Pecos River and the arid climate in which the lake is located.'

name: Caballo Lake State Park
description: b"Caballo Lake State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located 16 miles (26\xc2\xa0km) south of Truth or Consequences on the Rio Grande.[2] Caballo Lake was created in the 1930s when an earthen dam was built across the Rio Grande. The dam is 96 feet (29\xc2\xa0m) tall and 4,558 feet (1,389\xc2\xa0m) across. The size of the lake varies by season, but when the lake is full, it is over 11,500 acres (47\xc2\xa0km2) in area, and 18 miles (29\xc2\xa0km) long, making it New Mexico's third largest lake."

name: Cerrillos Hills State Park
description: b"Cerrillos Hills State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located 16 miles (26\xc2\xa0km) south of Santa Fe.  Transferred to state ownership in 2009, it is New Mexico's newest state park. The hills in the park range in elevation from 6,000 feet (1,800\xc2\xa0m) to 6,900 feet (2,100\xc2\xa0m) above sea level. The new visitors' center is located in the village of Los Cerrillos. \nThe park does have numerous hiking trails."

name: Cimarron Canyon State Park
description: b'Cimarron Canyon State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located 3 miles (4.8\xc2\xa0km) east of Eagle Nest in the Colin Neblett Wildlife Area. The park extends for 8 miles (13\xc2\xa0km) along the Cimarron Canyon between Tolby Creek and Ute Park. The Palisades Sill forms spectacular cliffs above the Cimarron River here.'

name: City of Rocks State Park
description: b'City of Rocks State Park is a state park in New Mexico, consisting of large sculptured rock formations in the shape of pinnacles or boulders rising as high as 40 feet (12\xc2\xa0m).'

name: Clayton Lake State Park
description: b"Clayton Lake State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, featuring a 170-acre (69\xc2\xa0ha) recreational reservoir and a fossil trackway of dinosaur footprints.  It is located 15 miles (24\xc2\xa0km) north of Clayton, close to New Mexico's border with Colorado, Oklahoma, and Texas. The park is accessed via New Mexico State Road 455. The landscape is characterized by rolling grasslands, volcanic rocks, and sandstone bluffs, set on the western edge of the Great Plains. The park area was a stopover point for travelers along the Cimarron Cutoff of the Santa Fe Trail."

name: Conchas Lake
description: b'Conchas Lake is a 25-mile (40\xc2\xa0km) long reservoir  in northeastern New Mexico, behind Conchas Dam on the Canadian River. The lake has an elevation of 4,200 feet (1309.2 meters) and a surface area of 9,600 acres.'

name: Coyote Creek State Park
description: b'Coyote Creek State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, preserving a riparian canyon in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains.  The park is located 17 miles (27\xc2\xa0km) north of Mora.  Coyote Creek is the most densely stocked trout stream in New Mexico.[2]'

name: Eagle Nest Lake State Park
description: b'Eagle Nest Lake State Park is a state park in New Mexico, United States.'

name: Elephant Butte Lake State Park
description: b'Elephant Butte Lake State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located 7 miles (11\xc2\xa0km) north of Truth or Consequences along the shore of Elephant Butte Reservoir in Sierra County.'

name: El Vado Lake
description: b'El Vado Lake is a reservoir located in Rio Arriba County, in northern New Mexico in the southwestern United States. Water is impounded by the earth-filled El Vado Dam, on the Rio Chama, 642 feet (196\xc2\xa0m) long and 175 feet (53\xc2\xa0m) high, completed in 1935.  The 3,200-acre (13\xc2\xa0km2) lake is 5 miles (8.0\xc2\xa0km) long and over 1 mile (1.6\xc2\xa0km) wide, and lies at an elevation of 6,900 feet (2,100\xc2\xa0m).'

name: Fenton Lake State Park
description: b'Fenton Lake State Park is a state park of New Mexico, USA, located 33 miles (53\xc2\xa0km) north of San Ysidro, in the Jemez Mountains.[2] The 37-acre (15\xc2\xa0ha) lake is a popular fishing destination.'

name: Heron Lake (New Mexico)
description: b'Heron Lake is a reservoir in Rio Arriba County, in northern New Mexico in the southwestern United States.  The lake is part of the San Juan-Chama Project, which transfers water from the upper reaches of the San Juan River through the 12.8-mile (20.6\xc2\xa0km) Azotea Tunnel (and under the Continental Divide), into Willow Creek and the Rio Chama (and ultimately into the Rio Grande).'

name: Hyde Memorial State Park
description: b'Hyde Memorial State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located 8 miles (13\xc2\xa0km) northeast of Santa Fe in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains.[2]  Summertime activities include hiking and camping, and in the winter the park is popular for tubing on the snow-covered hillsides.'

name: Leasburg Dam State Park
description: b'Leasburg Dam State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located on the Rio Grande.  It provides opportunities for camping, hiking, picnicking, swimming, and wildlife viewing.  Nearby is the historic Fort Seldon State Monument, and 15 miles (24\xc2\xa0km) to the south is the city of Las Cruces.'

name: Living Desert Zoo and Gardens State Park
description: b'The Living Desert Zoo and Gardens State Park, formerly the Living Desert Zoological and Botanical State Park, is a zoo and botanical garden displaying plants and animals of the Chihuahuan Desert in their native habitats. It is located off U.S. Route 285 at the north edge of Carlsbad, New Mexico, at an elevation of 3,200 feet (980\xc2\xa0m) atop the Ocotillo Hills overlooking the city and the Pecos River. It is open every day except Christmas.'

name: Manzano Mountains State Park
description: b'Manzano Mountains State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located 16 miles (26\xc2\xa0km) north of Mountainair on the eastern slope of the Manzano Mountains.[2] The park is popular for camping, bird-watching, hiking, and photography.'

name: Mesilla Valley Bosque State Park
description: b'Mesilla Valley Bosque State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, preserving a riverside forest (a bosque) along the Rio Grande.  The park is located near Las Cruces and just west of Mesilla.[1] The park itself encompasses approximately 305 acres (1.23\xc2\xa0km2), at an elevation of 3,900 feet (1,200\xc2\xa0m).'

name: Morphy Lake State Park
description: b"Morphy Lake State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located 7 miles (11\xc2\xa0km) southwest of Mora in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains.[2] The park is one of New Mexico's smaller state parks, at only 30 acres (120,000\xc2\xa0m2), and the lake has a surface area of approximately 15 acres (61,000\xc2\xa0m2)."

name: Navajo Lake
description: b'Navajo Lake is a reservoir located in San Juan County and Rio Arriba County[1] in northwestern New Mexico, in the southwestern United States.  Portions of the reservoir extend into Archuleta County in southern Colorado.  The lake is part of the Colorado River Storage Project, which here manages the upper reaches of the San Juan River, storing and releasing water that is used locally for irrigation, or ultimately reaching the Colorado River in Utah.  Water is impounded in Navajo Lake by the earth- and rock-filled Navajo Dam, 3,800 feet (1,200\xc2\xa0m) long and 400 feet (120\xc2\xa0m) high, completed in 1962.  The 15,600-acre (63\xc2\xa0km2) lake is over 25 miles (40\xc2\xa0km) long and lies at an elevation of up to 6,085 feet (1,855\xc2\xa0m).'

name: Oasis State Park
description: b'Oasis State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located north of Portales in Roosevelt County.[1] It is a common destination for nearby residents and features a small fishing lake and several sand dunes.'

name: Oliver Lee Memorial State Park
description: b"Oliver Lee Memorial State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, whose two tracts preserve a canyon in the Sacramento Mountains and Oliver Lee's historic 19th-century ranch house.  The 640-acre (260\xc2\xa0ha) park is located in Otero County at an elevation of 4,363 feet (1,330\xc2\xa0m).[1] It is situated at the base of Dog Canyon and provides opportunities for camping, hiking, picnicking, wildlife viewing, a nature trail, and guided tours of the ranch house."

name: Village of Columbus and Camp Furlong
description: b'The Village of Columbus and Camp Furlong is a National Historic Landmark District commemorating the 1916 raid by Pancho Villa on the town of Columbus, New Mexico, and the American military response to that raid, the "Punitive Expedition" led by General John J. Pershing.  The raid and its response, set during World War I, the Mexican Revolution, and an accompanying low-level Border War, played a significant role in diplomacy and military preparedness for eventual American entry in the World War.  The district encompasses buildings which survived the raid, and military facilities used in the American response. The landmark designation was made in 1975.[2][3]'

name: Percha Dam State Park
description: b"Percha Dam State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located 21 miles (34\xc2\xa0km) south of Truth or Consequences, New Mexico on the Rio Grande.[1] The park itself encompasses approximately 80 acres (32\xc2\xa0ha). The dam is less than 2 miles (3.2\xc2\xa0km) downstream of the much larger Caballo Dam, and therefore Percha Dam's reservoir is essentially a wide, slow moving section of river. The dam's purpose is to raise the elevation of the Rio Grande slightly to allow irrigation of the chile pepper crop downstream."

name: Rio Grande Nature Center State Park
description: b'The Rio Grande Nature Center State Park is a New Mexico State Park located adjacent to the Rio Grande in Albuquerque, New Mexico, USA. The Rio Grande Nature Center is a 38-acre urban wildlife preserve established in 1982. About two thirds of the grounds of the Park are set aside as habitat for wildlife. The remaining acreage contains a visitors center, two gardens, several wildlife viewing areas, an education building and a building housing the non-profit Wildlife Rescue, Inc. There are four constructed ponds which provide habitat for birds and other wildlife and which mimic wetland features of the historical flood plain of the Rio Grande.'

name: Rockhound State Park
description: b'Rockhound State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located 7 miles (11\xc2\xa0km) southeast of Deming.[1] It is named for the abundance of minerals in the area, and visitors can search for quartz crystals, geodes, jasper, perlite, and many other minerals. The park is located in the Little Florida Mountains, a range of low mountains that have become sky islands due to the arid desert between the peaks.'

name: Santa Rosa Lake State Park
description: b'Santa Rosa Lake State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located on the eastern plains.'

name: Storrie Lake State Park
description: b'Storrie Lake State Park is a state park in New Mexico, United States, located 4 miles (6.4\xc2\xa0km) north of Las Vegas, New Mexico in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains.[2] The land area of the park is only 81 acres (33\xc2\xa0ha), however the lake itself has a surface area of approximately 1,100 acres (450\xc2\xa0ha).'

name: Sugarite Canyon State Park
description: b'Sugarite Canyon State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, featuring a historic early-20th century coal-mining camp and natural scenery at the border of the Rocky Mountains and the Great Plains.  The park is located on the Colorado\xe2\x80\x93New Mexico state line 6 miles (9.7\xc2\xa0km) northeast of Raton, New Mexico.'

name: Sumner Lake State Park
description: b'Sumner Lake State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located on the eastern plains about 8 miles (13\xc2\xa0km) northwest of Fort Sumner.'

name: Ute Lake State Park
description: b'Ute Lake State Park is a state park in New Mexico, USA, located on the eastern plains.'

name: Vietnam Veterans Memorial (New Mexico)
description: b'Vietnam Veterans Memorial  is a memorial established in honor of Vietnam War veterans, near United States Highway 64 in Angel Fire, New Mexico.'

name: Villanueva State Park
description: b'Villanueva State Park is a state park of New Mexico, United States, located on the banks of the Pecos River. The park features red and yellow sandstone cliffs, cottonwood trees, and other native plants. The park elevation is 5,600 feet (1,700\xc2\xa0m) above sea level. The park is located 35 miles (56\xc2\xa0km) southwest of the town of Las Vegas, New Mexico.[2]'

name: A. W. Marion State Park
description: b"A. W. Marion State Park is a public recreation area located near Circleville, Ohio. The state park's 310 acres (130\xc2\xa0ha) are centered on 145-acre (59\xc2\xa0ha) Hargus Lake. The park offers hiking, picnicking, and boating.[2]"

name: Alum Creek State Park
description: b'Alum Creek State Park is a 4,630-acre (1,870\xc2\xa0ha) Ohio state park in Delaware County, Ohio, in the United States. Alum Creek Lake was constructed from 1970 to 1974 as part of the Flood Control Act of 1962. Alum Creek Dam was constructed on Alum Creek, a tributary of Big Walnut Creek, which drains into the Scioto River. Alum Creek Reservoir holds 3,387 acres (1,371\xc2\xa0ha) of water and is open to fishing, boating, ice fishing, ice boating and swimming. The park is just north of the state capital of Columbus and contains the remnants of a settlement by freed slaves that arrived in Ohio from North Carolina.[3]'

name: Barkcamp State Park
description: b'Barkcamp State Park is a public recreation area located in Belmont County, Ohio, United States, near the village of Belmont. The 1,005-acre (407\xc2\xa0ha) state park centers around 117-acre (47\xc2\xa0ha) Belmont Lake. The park offers camping including equestrian facilities, hiking and horseback trails, basketball courts, boat ramps, beach, and other recreational sites.[3]'

name: Beaver Creek State Park
description: b'Beaver Creek State Park is a 2,722-acre (1,102\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area  in Columbiana County, Ohio in the United States. The park is near East Liverpool on the banks of Little Beaver Creek. Remnants of the historic Sandy and Beaver Canal can be found throughout the park.  It is open for year-round recreation including, camping, boating, hunting, fishing and hiking.[2]'

name: Blue Rock State Park
description: b'Blue Rock State Park is a public recreation area located 11 miles (18\xc2\xa0km) southeast of Zanesville in Muskingum County, Ohio. The state park encompasses  322 acres (130\xc2\xa0ha) that are surrounded by the 4,573 acres (1,851\xc2\xa0ha) of Blue Rock State Forest.[2]'

name: Buck Creek State Park
description: b"Buck Creek State Park is a 4,016-acre (1,625\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area in Clark County, Ohio, in the United States, that is leased by the state of Ohio from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. The state park's main feature is the C. J. Brown Reservoir, a flood control reservoir created by the USACE on Buck Creek (or Lagonda Creek) as part of a flood control system in the Ohio River drainage basin. The park offers year-round recreation including camping, boating, hunting, fishing, swimming, picnicking, and hiking.[3]"

name: Buckeye Lake State Park
description: b'Buckeye Lake State Park is a public recreation area in Fairfield, Licking and Perry counties, Ohio in the United States. The park consists of a 3,349 acres (1,355\xc2\xa0ha) of shore areas, islands, and water. Shore areas and islands include Brooks Park, Fairfield Beach, Liebs Island, Mud Island and North Shore. Activities include boating, fishing, swimming, picnicking, wildlife observation. and winter recreation. Wildlife visible in or from the park include cormorants, herons, bald eagles, osprey, and numerous waterfowl.[3]'

name: Burr Oak State Park
description: b'Burr Oak State Park is a public recreation area located four miles (6.4\xc2\xa0km) northeast of Glouster in the U.S. state of Ohio. The park sits mostly in Morgan County, with part extending into Athens County.[3]'

name: Caesar Creek State Park
description: b'Caesar Creek State Park is a public recreation area located in southwestern Ohio, five miles (8\xc2\xa0km) east of Waynesville, in Warren, Clinton, and Greene counties.[2] The park is leased by the State from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, who in the 1970s erected a dam on Caesar Creek to impound a 2,830-acre (1,150\xc2\xa0ha) lake.[2]  The total park area, including the lake, is 7,530-acre (3,050\xc2\xa0ha).'

name: Catawba Island State Park
description: b"Catawba Island State Park is a ten-acre (4.0\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area located on Lake Erie, six miles northeast of Port Clinton, Ohio. Boating, fishing and picnicking are the major activities of the park. The state park, along with the other units in Ohio's Lake Erie state parks group, was established in the early 1950s.[2]"

name: Delaware State Park
description: b'Delaware State Park is a 1,686-acre (682\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area on U.S. Route 23 near the city of Delaware in Delaware County, Ohio, in the United States. It is open for year-round recreation including camping, hiking, boating, hunting, fishing, and picnicking.[2]'

name: East Fork State Park
description: b"East Fork State Park is 4,870-acre (1,970\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area located in Clermont County, twenty miles (32\xc2\xa0km) southeast of central Cincinnati, Ohio, in the United States. It has camping, hiking, swimming, and boating opportunities.[2] The state park has hosted junior and collegiate rowing races, including the US Rowing Youth National Championships.[3] The park's main feature is William H. Harsha Lake, a 2,107-acre (853\xc2\xa0ha) reservoir[4] created in 1978. The lake's large earthen dam and smaller saddle dams are operated by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.[5]"

name: East Harbor State Park
description: b'East Harbor State Park is a public recreation area located eight miles (13\xc2\xa0km) northwest of Sandusky, Ohio on the shores of Lake Erie. The state park includes beach, campground, marina, and wetland wildlife preserve areas. The park offers swimming, boating and fishing, ten miles (16\xc2\xa0km) of multi-use trails, picnicking, hunting, and disc golf.[2]'

name: Forked Run State Park
description: b'Forked Run State Park is a public recreation area located three miles (4.8\xc2\xa0km) south of Reedsville in eastern Meigs County, Ohio, United States. The state park\'s area is 791 acres (320\xc2\xa0ha), while the lake covers 102 acres (41\xc2\xa0ha).[2] The name is pronounced with two syllables for "Forked". It fronts on Ohio State Route 124. The park borders the Shade River State Forest, from which it was created in 1951. The dam was created in 1952, when the park was opened to the public.[2]'

name: Geneva State Park
description: b"Geneva State Park is a 698-acre (282\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area located on the shore of Lake Erie in Geneva, Ashtabula County, Ohio, United States. Park activities include hiking, camping, fishing, boating, canoeing and swimming, snowmobiling, cross-country skiing, and ice fishing. The state park offers access to Lake Erie's central basin through a six-lane boat ramp and marina. Overnight accommodations include a concessionaire-operated lodge with lakeside cottages.[2]"

name: Grand Lake St. Marys State Park
description: b'Grand Lake St. Marys State Park is a public recreation area located on 13,500-acre (5,500\xc2\xa0ha) Grand Lake in Mercer and Auglaize counties, Ohio.[4] Grand Lake is the largest inland lake in Ohio in terms of area, but is shallow, with an average depth of only 5\xe2\x80\x937 feet (1.5\xe2\x80\x932.1\xc2\xa0m). The state park is open for year-round recreation, including boating, fishing, swimming and hunting. The park consists of the lake and park facilities scattered all around the shore intermingled with private property and a facility operated by Wright State University.[3] It is west of St. Marys, and south-east of Celina, 23 miles (37\xc2\xa0km) south-west of Lima in the north-western part of Ohio.[1]'

name: Harrison Lake State Park
description: b'Harrison Lake State Park is a 142-acre (57\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area located three miles southwest of Fayette, Ohio, in the United States. The state park offers hiking trails, swimming beach, and campground.[2]'

name: Headlands Beach State Park
description: b'Headlands Beach State Park is a public beach in Mentor and Painesville Township, Ohio, United States. It is the longest natural beach in Ohio[3] and attracts two million visitors annually.[4] The breakwall at the eastern end of the park, frequented by fishermen, has Fairport Harbor West Breakwater Light. Amenities include hiking trails, playground, picnic areas, and the adjacent Headlands Dunes State Nature Preserve.[3][5]'

name: Hocking Hills State Park
description: b'Hocking Hills State Park is a state park in the Hocking Hills region of Hocking County, Ohio, United States. In some areas the park adjoins the Hocking State Forest. Within the park are over 25 miles (40\xc2\xa0km) of hiking trails, rock formations, waterfalls, and recess caves. The trails are open from dawn to dusk, all year round, including holidays.[1]'

name: Hueston Woods State Park
description: b"Hueston Woods State Park is a state park located in Butler and Preble counties of the U.S. state of Ohio, about five miles (8\xc2\xa0km) northeast of Oxford in the southwestern part of the state. The park lies in Oxford Township, Butler County, and Israel Township, Preble County. It has nearly 3,000 acres (1,200\xc2\xa0ha), including a man-made lake of 625 acres (253\xc2\xa0ha).[4] The park's beech-maple climax forest has been designated a National Natural Landmark.[5]"

name: Independence Dam State Park
description: b'Independence Dam State Park is a 591-acre (239\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area located on the banks of the Maumee River three miles east of Defiance in Defiance County, Ohio, United States. The state park features ruins of the Miami and Erie Canal. Recreational features include boating, fishing, hiking, picnicking, and primitive camping.[3]'

name: Jackson Lake State Park (Ohio)
description: b'Jackson Lake State Park is a public recreation area covering 106 acres (43\xc2\xa0ha) on the east side of Jackson Lake in Jackson County, Ohio, in the United States.[2][3] The park was established as a state park in 1979. It had previously been a "state reserve", similar to a park but with less development. The forests in and around Jackson Lake State Park were previously harvested to fire the furnaces of numerous iron works that were located in southern Ohio in the western foothills of the Appalachian Mountains. Recreational activities available at the park include camping, boating, fishing, swimming and picnicking.[2]'

name: John Bryan State Park
description: b'John Bryan State Park is a 752-acre (304\xc2\xa0ha) Ohio state park in Greene County, Ohio. The park surrounds Clifton Gorge, a deep cut of the Little Miami River between Yellow Springs and Clifton. The park contains a campground, and hiking and biking trails.[2] The park also abuts the Clifton Gorge State Nature Preserve and Glen Helen Nature Preserve.'

name: Kelleys Island State Park
description: b"Kelleys Island State Park is a public recreation area occupying one-quarter of Kelleys Island, an island in Lake Erie located 13 miles (21\xc2\xa0km) northeast of Port Clinton, Ohio, in the United States. The state park's 677 acres (274\xc2\xa0ha) include six miles (9.7\xc2\xa0km) of hiking trails, ruins of lime kilns and quarrying operations, sand beach, and campground. The park was established in 1956.[2] The park cooperates with other agencies to manage the adjoining Glacial Grooves State Memorial, a set of rare glacial grooves,[3] North Shore Alvar State Natural Area, a rare alvar habitat,[4] and the North Pond State Nature Preserve, a lake embayment usually separated from the lake by a sand bar.[5]"

name: Kiser Lake State Park
description: b'Kiser Lake State Park is a public recreation area in Champaign County, Ohio, located four miles (6.4\xc2\xa0km) northwest of St. Paris and 34 miles (55\xc2\xa0km) north of Dayton.[2] The 531-acre (215\xc2\xa0ha) state park includes 396-acre (160\xc2\xa0ha) Kiser Lake, for which it was named, and the 51-acre (21\xc2\xa0ha) Kiser Lake Wetlands State Nature Preserve.[3][4]'

name: Lake Hope State Park
description: b'Lake Hope State Park is a public recreation area encompassing 2,983 acres (1,207\xc2\xa0ha) within Zaleski State Forest, located five miles (8.0\xc2\xa0km) northeast of Zaleski in Vinton County, Ohio.[3] The state park is centered on Lake Hope, a 120-acre (49\xc2\xa0ha) impoundment on Big Sandy Run.[4]'

name: Lake Loramie State Park
description: b'Lake Loramie State Park is a public recreation area located on the northeast side of Fort Loramie, Ohio. It occupies 407 acres (165\xc2\xa0ha) on 1,655-acre (670\xc2\xa0ha) Lake Loramie[3] and is operated by the Ohio Department of Natural Resources.[4]'

name: Lake White State Park
description: b'Lake White State Park is a public recreation area located on the southwest edge of Waverly in Pike County, Ohio, United States.[3] The state park contains 92 acres (37\xc2\xa0ha) of land and 337 acres (136\xc2\xa0ha) of water.[2]'

name: Little Miami Scenic Trail
description: b'The Little Miami Scenic Trail is the third longest paved trail in the United States,[5] running 78.1 miles (125.7\xc2\xa0km)[1] through five southwestern counties in the state of Ohio. The multi-use rail trail sees heavy recreational use by hikers and bicyclists, as well as the occasional horseback rider. Over 700,000 people made use of the trail in 2014.[6]'

name: Madison Lake State Park
description: b'Madison Lake State Park is a public recreation area located four miles southeast of London in the Darby Plains region of Madison County, Ohio, in the United States.[3] The state park includes the 106 acres (43\xc2\xa0ha) Madison Lake, for which it was named, and an additional 76 acres (31\xc2\xa0ha) of land surrounding the lake.'

name: Mary Jane Thurston State Park
description: b'Mary Jane Thurston State Park is a 105-acre (42\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area  lying along the Maumee River near remains of the historic Miami and Erie Canal in Wood and Henry counties, Ohio, in the United States. It is named for Mary Jane Thurston, a schoolteacher from Grand Rapids, Ohio, who bequeathed land for the establishment of a park. The state park is open for year-round recreation including, hunting, fishing and boating, picnicking, camping, and hiking.[2]'

name: Maumee Bay State Park
description: b'Maumee Bay State Park is a 1,336-acre (541\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area located on the shores of Lake Erie, five miles east of Toledo, in Jerusalem Township, Lucas County, Ohio, United States. Major features of the state park include a lodge and conference center, cottages, camping facilities, golf course, nature center, and two-mile-long interpretive boardwalk. Common activities include hiking, picnicking, fishing, hunting, boating, swimming, winter sports, and geocaching. The site was acquired by the state in 1974 and became a state park in 1975.[3]'

name: Mohican State Park
description: b'Mohican State Park is a 1,110-acre (450\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area located on the south shore of Pleasant Hill Lake, five miles (8.0\xc2\xa0km) south of Loudonville in Ashland County, Ohio, United States.[3] The state park is located along Ohio SR 3 and Ohio SR 97 and is surrounded by the 4,525-acre (1,831\xc2\xa0ha) Mohican-Memorial State Forest. The Clear Fork of the Mohican River flows through the park carving a narrow gorge and joins the Black Fork about a half-mile east of the park to form the Mohican River. The park is open for year-round recreation including camping, hiking, boating, mountain biking, fishing, and picnicking.[4][5]'

name: Mount Gilead State Park
description: b'Mt. Gilead State Park is a public recreation area located immediately to the east of the village of Mount Gilead in Morrow County, Ohio, United States. The state park covers 181 acres (73\xc2\xa0ha), 32 of which are the upper and lower lakes. It offers hiking, camping, picnicking, fishing and electric-motor boating as well as wintertime ice skating, ice fishing, and cross-country skiing. Access to the park is via State Route 95.[3]'

name: Nelson Kennedy Ledges State Park
description: b'Nelson-Kennedy Ledges State Park is a 167-acre (68\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area offering trails and picnicking located in Nelson Township, Portage County, Ohio, United States.[3] Within the park are angled rock formations 50 to 60 feet (18\xc2\xa0m) high with ground fissures as deep as 60 feet (18\xc2\xa0m). It is accessible from U.S. Route 422 and State Route 305 via State Route 282.[4]'

name: Paint Creek State Park
description: b"Paint Creek State Park is a 5,652-acre (2,287\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area located in Highland and Ross counties in the U.S. state of Ohio. The state park's central feature is a reservoir, 1,148-acre (465\xc2\xa0ha) Paint Creek Lake,[2] which was created by the damming of Paint Creek. Construction on the dam started in 1967, and Paint Creek State Park was opened in 1972.[3][4]"

name: Pike Lake State Park (Ohio)
description: b'Pike Lake State Park is a public recreation area located in the midst of the wooded hills of Pike County, five miles south of the village of Bainbridge, in the southern part of the U.S. state of Ohio. The state park contains a small lake with surrounding state forest, campground, and cabins. The site was developed by members of the Civilian Conservation Corps in the 1930s and became a state park in 1949.[3]'

name: Portage Lakes State Park
description: b'Portage Lakes State Park is a public recreation area located around the Portage Lakes in New Franklin, Ohio, in the United States. The eight Portage Lakes encompass 2,034 acres (823\xc2\xa0ha) used for boating, fishing, and swimming.[2] The Ohio Department of Public Works turned over maintenance of the lakes to the Ohio Department of Natural Resources Division of Parks and Recreation in 1949.[3]'

name: Punderson State Park
description: b'Punderson State Park is a 741-acre (300\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area in Newbury, Ohio. The state park features a 150-acre (61\xc2\xa0ha) lake[2] and a lodge that enjoys a reputation for being haunted. The state park has facilities for swimming, fishing, camping, golf, disc golf, and sledding in wintertime.[3]'

name: Pymatuning State Park (Ohio)
description: b'Pymatuning State Park is a 3512\xc2\xa0acres (14.21\xc2\xa0km2) Ohio state park near Andover, Ashtabula County, Ohio in the United States. Pymatuning State Park contains 1,407\xc2\xa0acres (5.69\xc2\xa0km2) of Pymatuning Lake, one-quarter of which is in Ohio and three-quarters of which is in Pennsylvania.[4] The lake provides fishing and boating year round.[3]'

name: Quail Hollow State Park
description: b'Quail Hollow Park is a 703-acre (284\xc2\xa0ha) county park in Stark County, Ohio, in the United States. The park was opened to the public in 1975. It was previously a privately owned family farm and later a hunting camp. Quail Hollow Park is open for year-round recreation and features trail that are open to hiking, mountain biking and cross-country skiing, a small pond for fishing and ice skating as well as group camping (advance reservation only) and picnic facilities.[2]'

name: Rocky Fork State Park (Ohio)
description: b"Rocky Fork State Park is a public recreation area located in Highland County, Ohio, United States.[4] The state park's central feature is 2,080-acre (840\xc2\xa0ha) Rocky Fork Lake and its 31 miles (50\xc2\xa0km) of shoreline.[5] The lake was added to the state park system in 1950. The park offers marinas, boat ramps, swimming beaches, picnic areas, hiking trails and nature center.[4] Two significant archaeological sites dating from the Hopewellian period are located in the park, the Rocky Fork Park Group and the Rocky Fork Park Site.[6]"

name: Salt Fork State Park
description: b'Salt Fork State Park is a public recreation area located six miles (9.7\xc2\xa0km) north of Lore City in Guernsey County, Ohio.[3] It is the largest state park in Ohio, encompassing  17,229 acres (6,972\xc2\xa0ha) of land and 2,952 acres (1,195\xc2\xa0ha) of water. The grounds include the Kennedy Stone House, which is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The park is managed by the Ohio Department of Natural Resources Division of Parks and Watercraft.[2]'

name: Shawnee State Park (Ohio)
description: b'Shawnee State Park is a 1,095-acre (443\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area surrounded by the 63,000-acre (25,000\xc2\xa0ha) Shawnee State Forest in Scioto County, Ohio, United States. The park is in the foothills of the Appalachian Mountains near the Ohio River in Southern Ohio on State Route 125, just north of Friendship.[2]'

name: Stonelick State Park
description: b'Stonelick State Park is a public recreation area located off Ohio State Route 727, 24 miles (39\xc2\xa0km) east of central Cincinnati, in Wayne Township, Clermont County, Ohio, United States. The state park covers 1,058 acres (428\xc2\xa0ha) of land and 200 acres (81\xc2\xa0ha) of water. Park activities include fishing, hunting, hiking, picnicking, swimming, boating, and camping.[2]'

name: Strouds Run State Park
description: b'Strouds Run State Park is a public recreation area abutting the city of Athens in Athens County, Ohio, in the United States. The state park is located primarily in Canaan Township, with a small part in Ames Township. Park boundaries coincide with Athens city limits in several places. The park comprises 2,606 acres (1,055\xc2\xa0ha), and includes Dow Lake, a 161-acre (65\xc2\xa0ha) artificial lake.[3][4]'

name: Tar Hollow State Park
description: b'Tar Hollow State Park is a public recreation area located five miles south of Laurelville, Ohio, in the United States. Surrounded by the foothills of the Appalachian Plateau, the state park is part of a larger protected complex with the adjoining Tar Hollow State Forest. The park offers hiking trails that extend into the state forest in addition to boating, fishing and swimming on 15-acre (6.1\xc2\xa0ha) Pine Lake.[3]'

name: Tinkers Creek State Park
description: b"Tinkers Creek State Park is a public recreation area that under the name Tinkers Creek Area is part of Liberty Park in Streetsboro, Portage County, Ohio, United States. The area's small lakes and marshes provide food and habitat for beavers and thousands of waterfowl. The park offers archery, spring-fed fishing lake, hiking trails, and picnicking areas.[2][3]"

name: Van Buren State Park (Ohio)
description: b'Van Buren State Park is a 296-acre (120\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area in Van Buren, Hancock County, Ohio, in the United States.[2] The state park centers on 53-acre (21\xc2\xa0ha) Van Buren Lake.[3] It is in a small patch of woods in Northwestern Ohio surrounded by thousands of acres of fields of corn, wheat and soybeans, and is open for year-round recreation.'

name: West Branch State Park
description: b'West Branch State Park is a public recreation area located east of Ravenna, Ohio, on the west branch of the Mahoning River. The park encompasses more than 5,000 acres (2,000\xc2\xa0ha) of land and 2,650 acres (1,070\xc2\xa0ha) of water mainly in Charlestown, Edinburg, and Paris townships, with additional land in neighboring Palmyra, Ravenna, and Rootstown townships. Activities include boating, fishing, and swimming on the Michael J. Kirwan Reservoir, hiking, and camping.[3]'

name: Wolf Run State Park
description: b'Wolf Run State Park is a 1,338-acre (541\xc2\xa0ha) public recreation area located three miles north of the village of Caldwell, Ohio, in the United States. The state park features hiking on trails that include a section of the Buckeye Trail plus swimming, boating and fishing on 220-acre (89\xc2\xa0ha) Wolf Run Lake.[2][3]'

name: Alabaster Caverns State Park
description: b'Alabaster Caverns State Park is a 200-acre (0.81\xc2\xa0km2) state park approximately 4.5 miles (7.2\xc2\xa0km) south of Freedom, Oklahoma, United States near Oklahoma State Highway 50.[3] The park attracted 24,706 visitors in FY 2016, The lowest count of the three parks in its part of Oklahoma.[a] According to the Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture, the park Previously attracted about 40,000 visitors per year. It is home to the largest natural gypsum cave in the world that is open to the public.[3] The gypsum is mostly in the form of alabaster. There are several types of alabaster found at the site, including pink, white, and the rare black alabaster. This black alabaster can be found in only three veins in the world, one each in Oklahoma, Italy and China. Another form of gypsum can be found in the many selenite crystal formations.[4]'

name: Arrowhead State Park
description: b'The former Arrowhead State Park, now known as the Arrowhead Area at Lake Eufaula State Park[2] is a 2,200-acre (8.9\xc2\xa0km2) Oklahoma state park area located in northern Pittsburg County, Oklahoma on a peninsula of Eufaula Lake.  It is located near the city of Canadian, Oklahoma.  Eufaula is one of the largest man-made lakes in the southwest. Arrowhead State Park features 100 tent sites and 91 total RV sites. The park also offers picnic shelters, a marina, playgrounds, trails, miniature golf course, swimming area, mountain biking, equestrian campground, stables, and 25 miles (40\xc2\xa0km) of equestrian trails. Group camps with a kitchen and bunkhouses are available and can sleep up to 144 people. Area 51 Marina, which also offers a restaurant, is also located at the park in the Echo Ridge area.[3]'

name: Beavers Bend Resort Park
description: b'Beavers Bend State Park is a 1,300 acres (5.3\xc2\xa0km2) Oklahoma state park located in McCurtain County. It is  approximately 10.5 miles (16.9\xc2\xa0km) north of Broken Bow on SH-259A.[1] It was established in 1937 and contains Broken Bow Lake.[2]'

name: Bernice State Park
description: b"Bernice State Park, also called Bernice Area at Grand Lake State Park, is an 88-acre (360,000\xc2\xa0m2) Oklahoma state park located in Delaware County, Oklahoma.  It is located near the city of Bernice, Oklahoma at the northwestern corner of Grand Lake o' the Cherokees. The park is actually across the mouth of the Neosho River from the town of Bernice.[1]"

name: Black Mesa State Park
description: b'Black Mesa State Park is an Oklahoma state park  in Cimarron County, near the western border of the Oklahoma panhandle and New Mexico. The park is located about 15 miles (24\xc2\xa0km) away from its namesake, Black Mesa, the highest point in Oklahoma (4,973 feet (1,516\xc2\xa0m) above sea level). The mesa was named for the layer of black lava rock that coats it.[2]'

name: Boiling Springs State Park
description: b'Boiling Springs State Park is a park built 6 miles (9.7\xc2\xa0km) northeast of Woodward, Oklahoma, USA.[3] It was built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in the 1930s.'

name: Cherokee Landing State Park
description: b'Cherokee Landing State Park is a 146-acre (0.59\xc2\xa0km2) Oklahoma state park located in Cherokee County, Oklahoma.  It is located near Park Hill, Oklahoma on a peninsula jutting into Lake Tenkiller in the Cookson Hills, south of Tahlequah. The park features 93 RV campsites with electric power and water hookups, dump station, 45 primitive campsites, covered picnic shelters, restrooms with hot showers, boating, lighted boat ramp, water skiing, swimming beach, fishing, handicapped fishing dock, playgrounds and a softball field.[2]'

name: Cherokee State Park (Oklahoma)
description: b"Cherokee State Park is a 43-acre (170,000\xc2\xa0m2) Oklahoma state park located in Mayes County, Oklahoma.  It is located near the city of Disney, Oklahoma. Cherokee State Park is located in northeastern Oklahoma on the west shore of Grand Lake o' the Cherokees, one of Oklahoma's largest lakes with over 59,000 acres (240\xc2\xa0km2) and 1,300 miles (2,100\xc2\xa0km) of shoreline. The park consists of several smaller parks that are located near the Pensacola Dam and around the lake. The area is known for great fishing and a variety of water sports. Amenities include picnic sites, a group shelter, campsites, playgrounds, comfort stations, lighted boat ramp and a 9-hole golf course.[1]"

name: Clayton Lake State Park (Oklahoma)
description: b'Clayton Lake State Park is a 510-acre (2.1\xc2\xa0km2) Oklahoma state park located in Pushmataha County, Oklahoma, 5 miles (8.0\xc2\xa0km) south of Clayton, Oklahoma.[1] It has RV sites and tent camping areas, along with primitive cabins, one family-style two bedroom cabin, picnic tables, group picnic shelters, comfort stations with showers, and boat ramps. The park also has an ADA accessible fishing dock, playground, hiking trails, and swimming beach.[2]'

name: Disney/Little Blue State Park
description: b'Disney/Little Blue State Park is a 32-acre (130,000\xc2\xa0m2) Oklahoma state park located near Disney, Oklahoma in the eastern part of the state. The park is a popular site for bass fishing and water sports.[1]'

name: Fort Cobb State Park
description: b"Fort Cobb State Park is a 1,872-acre (7.58\xc2\xa0km2) Oklahoma state park located in Caddo County, Oklahoma, USA. It is located near the city of Fort Cobb. The park offers recreational activities and facilities including camping, fishing, boating, water sports, golf, hunting and swimming. A visitors' center is located on site, as well as a gift shop, bait and tackle shop, RV sites with water and electric hook-ups, primitive camping areas, scenic views of the lake, comfort stations, showers, picnic sites, group shelters, a playground, swimming beach and marina. Equipment rentals are available. The park also has an 18-hole golf course with practice range, putting green and pro shop. The park has 299 RV sites and 300 tent campsites.[2]"

name: Foss State Park
description: b'Foss State Park is a 1,749-acre (708\xc2\xa0ha) Oklahoma state park located on Foss Lake, in southwestern Custer County, Oklahoma, near the city of Foss.'

name: Gloss Mountain State Park
description: b'Glass Mountains State Park (also called Gloss Mountain State Park) is an Oklahoma state park located in Major County, Oklahoma, near the city of Fairview, Oklahoma.[a]  A recreational-educational park that is accessible 365 days a year for hiking and picnicking, from sunrise to sunset. There are no campsites or other overnight accommodations in the park. Facilities include a restroom, pavilions, picnic areas, grills, public water supply, handicap trail to historical marker, and a hiking trail from base parking lot to the top of Cathedral Mountain and across the mesa to view the valley floor and Lone Peak Mountain. Points of interest include land geography, geological formations, Selenite gypsum, scenery and wildlife. This range is also known as the Glass Mountains.[3]'

name: Great Plains State Park
description: b'Great Plains State Park is a 487-acre (1.97\xc2\xa0km2) Oklahoma state park located in Kiowa County, Oklahoma.  It is located near the city of Mountain Park, Oklahoma.  Located south of Hobart off Hwy 183, Great Plains State Park is nestled between the Wichita Mountains and the Tom Steed Reservoir.[a] The area offers water sports, boating, boat ramps, camping, RV parking, swimming beach, playground, picnic areas, cycling, mountain biking and hiking trails. The campground spans approximately 460 acres (1.9\xc2\xa0km2) of park land with 56 RV hookups and 30 tent sites. RV sites consist of 14 modern water, sewer, and electric sites and 42 semi-modern sites with water and electric. Located on the shores of Tom Steed Reservoir, a large lake with 31 miles (50\xc2\xa0km) of shoreline.[2]'

name: Great Salt Plains State Park
description: b'Great Salt Plains State Park is a 840-acre (3.4\xc2\xa0km2) Oklahoma state park located in Alfalfa County, Oklahoma.  It is located 8 miles (13\xc2\xa0km) north of Jet, Oklahoma on SH-38 and 12 miles (19\xc2\xa0km) east of Cherokee.[2]   Recreational opportunities at Great Salt Plains State Park include boating, camping, picnicking, swimming, hiking, mountain biking and exploring. The Great Salt Plains Lake is located at the park and covers 9,300 acres (38\xc2\xa0km2) with 41 miles (66\xc2\xa0km) of shoreline and is a shallow, salty lake with fishing opportunities for catfish, saugeye, sandbass and hybrid striper. The average depth is reportedly 4 feet (1.2\xc2\xa0m) and the impoundment capacity is 31,420 acre-feet. Salinity of the water in the reservoir is one-fourth that of sea water. Personal watercraft are not recommended. The park has RV and tent sites, comfort stations with showers, cabins, picnic sites, group shelters, swimming beach, playgrounds, boat ramps, fishing dock and equestrian trails. Horse rental is not available.[3]'

name: Greenleaf State Park
description: b'Greenleaf State Park is located near Braggs, Oklahoma, and is situated around the 930-acre (3.8\xc2\xa0km2) Greenleaf Lake. Greenleaf Lake was built in 1939.[2] There is an 18-mile (29\xc2\xa0km) hiking trail that begins inside the park and makes its way around Greenleaf lake and into the adjacent government land of Camp Gruber.[3]'

name: Honey Creek State Park
description: b'The Honey Creek Area at Grand Lake State Park, previously Honey Creek State Park, is a 30-acre (120,000\xc2\xa0m2) Oklahoma state park located on Grand Lake, near the city of Grove, Oklahoma in Delaware County, Oklahoma[1]'

name: Hugo Lake
description: b"Hugo Lake is manmade lake located 7 miles (11\xc2\xa0km) east of Hugo, in Choctaw County, Oklahoma, United States.[1]  It is formed by Hugo Lake Dam on the Kiamichi River 18 miles (29\xc2\xa0km) upstream from the Red River.  The dam is visible from U.S. Route 70, which crosses its spillway just west of Sawyer.  Lake Hugo features approximately 110 miles (180\xc2\xa0km) of shoreline and covers over 13,250 acres (53.6\xc2\xa0km2), or 20 square miles (52\xc2\xa0km2).  Its normal pool elevation is 404.5 feet (123.3\xc2\xa0m) above sea level and its normal storage capacity is 157,600 acre feet (194,400,000\xc2\xa0m3).  At flood stage its elevation is at 437.5 feet (133.4\xc2\xa0m) above sea level and it is capable of storing 966,700 acre feet (1.1924\xc3\x97109\xc2\xa0m3) of flood waters.  The lake's primary functions are to provide flood control, water storage, and recreational opportunities.[2]"

name: Keystone State Park (Oklahoma)
description: b'Keystone State Park is an Oklahoma state park near Sand Springs, Tulsa County, Oklahoma, in the United States. Located on Keystone Lake, the park covers 714 acres (289\xc2\xa0ha) and provides recreational opportunities for fishing, swimming, water skiing and boating. Cabins are available to rent. Keystone State Park is on State Highway 151 near Mannford.[2]'

name: Lake Eufaula State Park
description: b"Lake Eufaula State Park is a 2,853-acre (11.55\xc2\xa0km2) Oklahoma state park located in McIntosh County, Oklahoma on Lake Eufaula. It is 14 miles (23\xc2\xa0km) southwest of Checotah. The park was formerly known as Fountainhead State Park. Fountainhead, together with the neighboring Arrowhead State Park, were created in 1965. Fountainhead's name was changed to Lake Eufaula State Park effective November 1, 2002.[2]  Arrowhead is now known as the Arrowhead Area at Lake Eufaula State Park.[3]"

name: Lake Murray (Oklahoma)
description: b"Lake Murray is a 5,700-acre (23\xc2\xa0km2) lake in south central Oklahoma, near Ardmore named for Oklahoma Governor William H. Murray.[1]  It was created by damming Anadarche and Fourche Maline Creeks.[2] The lake is wholly within Lake Murray State Park, Oklahoma's largest state park, containing over 12,500 acres (51\xc2\xa0km\xc2\xb2) of relative wilderness.  A state-operated lodge and resort is located on the west shore that serves many visitors to the lake, and serves as a base for numerous cabin and campground facilities near the lake.[3]"

name: Lake Texoma
description: b"Lake Texoma is one of the largest reservoirs in the United States, the 12th largest US Army Corps of Engineers' (USACE) lake, and the largest in USACE Tulsa District.[1] Lake Texoma is formed by Denison Dam on the Red River in Bryan County, Oklahoma, and Grayson County, Texas, about 726 miles (1,168\xc2\xa0km) upstream from the mouth of the river. It is located at the confluence of the Red and Washita Rivers. The project was completed in 1944. The damsite is about 5 miles (8.0\xc2\xa0km) northwest of Denison, Texas, and 15 miles (24\xc2\xa0km) southwest of Durant, Oklahoma. Lake Texoma is the most developed and most popular lake within the USACE Tulsa District, attracting around 6 million visitors a year.[1] Oklahoma has more of the lake within its boundaries than Texas."

name: Lake Thunderbird State Park
description: b'Lake Thunderbird State Park is a 1,874 acres (7.58\xc2\xa0km2) Oklahoma state park located in Cleveland County, Oklahoma.  It is 12 miles (19\xc2\xa0km) east of Norman, Oklahoma on State Highway 9.[1]'

name: Lake Wister State Park
description: b'Lake Wister State Park is a 3,428-acre (13.87\xc2\xa0km2) Oklahoma state park located in Le Flore County, Oklahoma.  It is located near the city of Wister, Oklahoma.'

name: Little Sahara State Park
description: b'Little Sahara State Park , also called Waynoka Dunes [1] is a state park located in Woods County, Oklahoma, named for its resemblance to the Sahara Desert. The vast dunes have formed over time from terrace deposits, remnants of prehistoric times when the Cimarron River flowed over the entire area.[2]'

name: McGee Creek State Park
description: b'McGee Creek State Park is a state park in southern Oklahoma. The park is on the south side of McGee Creek Reservoir.  Created in 1985 the reservoir provides flood control.  The park is approximately 2,600 acres (1,100\xc2\xa0ha) and the reservoir is approximately 3,800 acres (1,500\xc2\xa0ha).  Its main staple is recreational and sport fishing. The main fish fished for in this park include Crappie, Sunfish, Largemouth bass, and Channel catfish.  The McGee Creek Wildlife Management area is located between the two arms of the reservoir.[2]'

name: Natural Falls State Park
description: b'Natural Falls State Park is a 120 acres (0.49\xc2\xa0km2) state-owned park in the Ozarks, in Delaware County, Oklahoma. It lies along U.S. Highway 412, near the Arkansas-Oklahoma state line.[a] The property was privately-owned and known as Dripping Springs until 1990, when the state bought it. The previous owners had also used the property as an attraction and rest stop for travelers on the highway, featuring a swimming pool and gardens. The site was used in the production of the 1974 film "Where the Red Fern Grows".[2]'

name: Osage Hills State Park
description: b"Osage Hills State Park is a 1,100-acre (4.5\xc2\xa0km2) Oklahoma state park It is located in eastern Osage County, Oklahoma. The nearest cities are Pawhuska and Bartlesville. The park offers outdoor recreation opportunities including camping, hiking, fishing and wildlife watching. Park facilities include picnic tables and shelters, 20 semi-modern RV campsites, 16 tent sites and 8 cabins. Several of the park's structures are historic parkitecture built by the Civilian Conservation Corps during the 1930s and 1940s."

name: Quartz Mountain Nature Park
description: b'Quartz Mountain State Park is located in southwest Oklahoma at the western end of the Wichita Mountains, 13 miles (21\xc2\xa0km) east of Mangum, Oklahoma and 20 miles (32\xc2\xa0km) north of Altus, Oklahoma.  The nearest community is Lone Wolf, Oklahoma, about 9 miles (14\xc2\xa0km) northeast of the park. It is operated by Oklahoma State Park. The park began as a 158.3-acre tract adjacent to Lake Altus donated to the state by local residents, who had bought the land for $51.58.  It was designated as Quartz Mountain State Park, one of the original seven Oklahoma State Parks designated in 1935. Additional land has been donated since then, and the park now encompasses 4,540 acres (18.4\xc2\xa0km2).[2] The park occupies land on the west side of Lake Altus-Lugert, which was originally built in 1927, then expanded in 1940 and renamed Lake Altus-Lugert. The park contains 4,284 acres (17.34\xc2\xa0km2) of land and more than 6,000 acres (24\xc2\xa0km2) of water.[3]'

name: Raymond Gary State Park
description: b'Raymond Gary State Park is an Oklahoma state park located in southeast Oklahoma. The park borders Raymond Gary Lake, which covers 263 acres (106\xc2\xa0ha) and offers opportunities for fishing, boating, swimming, and camping.[2][3][4]'

name: Robbers Cave State Park
description: b'Robbers Cave State Park is a state park in Latimer County, Oklahoma. It is located 5 miles (8.0\xc2\xa0km) north of Wilburton, Oklahoma, on State Highway 2. Originally named Latimer State Park, it received its current name in 1936. It is located in the scenic, hilly woodlands of the Sans Bois Mountains of southeast Oklahoma. This park is a favorite of rappellers, equestrians, hikers and outdoor lovers. The park and adjoining wildlife management area covers more than 8,000 acres (3,200\xc2\xa0ha) and includes three lakes. It offers visitors acres of discovery and enjoyment including trout fishing in season, boating, hunting, mountain biking, trails for hikers and horses, sandstone cliffs for climbing and rappelling, and fall foliage viewing.  In addition, Robbers Cave is historically notable as a former hideout for infamous outlaws Belle Starr and Jesse James.[1]'

name: Roman Nose State Park
description: b'Roman Nose State Park is a state park located in Blaine County, 7 miles (11\xc2\xa0km) north of Watonga, Oklahoma.[2]  Roman Nose State Park is one of the original seven Oklahoma state parks.[2]  Sitting in a small canyon, recreation activities at this state park include a golf course, swimming pools, hiking trails, two lakes (Lake Watonga and Lake Boecher), trout fishing in season, canoeing, paddle boats, mountain biking, horse stables and hayrides.[3]'

name: Sequoyah Bay State Park
description: b'Sequoyah Bay State Park is on the western shore of Fort Gibson Lake in Wagoner County, Oklahoma. It is 4.3 miles (6.9\xc2\xa0km) south of Wagoner, Oklahoma on State Highway 16. It offers several campgrounds, each named for a notable chief of the Five Civilized Tribes. These include: Chief Attacullaculla, Cherokee; Chief Pushmataha, Choctaw; Chief Osceola, Seminole; Chief Opothleyahola, Creek; and Chief Payamataha, Chickasaw.[1][2]'

name: Sequoyah State Park
description: b"Sequoyah State Park, one of Oklahoma State Park's 32 parks, is a 2,200 acre peninsular recreation space on the eastern shore of Fort Gibson Lake in Cherokee County, Oklahoma. It is 8 miles (13\xc2\xa0km) east of Wagoner, Oklahoma and 18 miles (29\xc2\xa0km) west of Tahlequah, Oklahoma on State Highway 51. A shortleaf pine-lined drive leads you to the many amenities of the park including camping loops, Paradise Cove Marina, a golf course, Three Forks Nature Center, Sequoyah Riding Stables, and the state's largest state park lodge. The park office is in the town of Hulbert, Oklahoma. There are 12 miles of hiking trails free and open to the public including the Fossil Trail, Bluebird Trail, and Scissortail Paved Trial."

name: Talimena State Park
description: b'Talimena State Park is an Oklahoma state park located in LeFlore County in eastern Oklahoma. The 20 acres (8.1\xc2\xa0ha) park is at the Oklahoma entrance to Talimena Scenic Drive, about 7 miles (11\xc2\xa0km) north of Talihina, Oklahoma.[2] and 20 miles (32\xc2\xa0km) south of Wister.  It offers opportunities for camping, hiking, biking, and wildlife watching.[3]'

name: Tenkiller State Park
description: b'Tenkiller State Park is a 1,190-acre (4.8\xc2\xa0km2) Oklahoma state park located in northwestern Sequoyah County, Oklahoma, near the city of Vian, Oklahoma.[2] Larger cities nearby include Sallisaw, Muskogee and Webbers Falls, Oklahoma. [a]'

name: Adair Park (Stilwell, Oklahoma)
description: b'Adair Park, formerly named Adair State Park, is located in the city of Stilwell, Oklahoma in Adair County, Oklahoma., adjacent to the Adair County fairgrounds. The 25-acre (100,000\xc2\xa0m2)  park offers 7 RV campsites and 20 primitive campsites, as well as a fishing pond, playground, comfort station with showers, covered shelters and picnic facilities.[1][2] The park also contains a fishing pond that covers 15-acre (61,000\xc2\xa0m2). Fishing is allowed from the shore of the pond.[3]'

name: Beaver Dunes Park
description: b'Beaver Dunes Park is in Beaver County, Oklahoma, near the city of Beaver.  The  520-acre (2.1\xc2\xa0km2)  park, located in the panhandle region of Oklahoma, offers dune buggy riding on 300 acres (1.2\xc2\xa0km2) of sand hills, fishing, hiking trails, a playground and two campgrounds. Hackberry Bend Campground is located next to Beaver Lake, approximately 2 acres (8,100\xc2\xa0m2), stocked with largemouth bass, channel catfish, and perch, and has 7 RV sites and 10 tent sites. Also located in Hackberry Bend is a one-room primitive cabin which sleeps four and can be reserved. Pioneer Campground is located adjacent to the ORV area. This campground has 13 RV sites with direct access to the dunes. Both campgrounds have a comfort station with hot showers. Dump station located at Hackberry Bend Campground. Both campgrounds have handicap accessibility. Another area of the park is Big Sandy picnic area. This area has a sand volleyball court, basketball goal, horseshoe pits, playground, nature trail, and two reservable shelters.[1]'

name: Boggy Depot, Oklahoma
description: b'Boggy Depot is a ghost town and Oklahoma State Park that was formerly a significant city in the Indian Territory. It grew as a vibrant and thriving town in present-day Atoka County, Oklahoma, United States and became a major trading center on the Texas Road and the Butterfield Overland Mail route between Missouri and San Francisco. After the Civil War, when the MKT Railroad came through the area, it bypassed Boggy Depot and the town began a steady decline. It was soon replaced by Atoka as the chief city in the area.  By the early 20th century, all that remained of the community was a sort of ghost town.'

name: Brushy Lake Park (Sallisaw, Oklahoma)
description: b'Brushy Lake Park is a 90-acre (360,000\xc2\xa0m2) former Oklahoma state park located in Sequoyah County, Oklahoma, 8 miles (13\xc2\xa0km) north of the city of Sallisaw, Oklahoma.  Located in the scenic wooded Cookson Hills of eastern Oklahoma beside the 300 acres (120\xc2\xa0ha) Brushy Lake,[1] this park offers visitors a quiet, secluded recreation destination with camping, picnic areas, fishing and boating. Facilities include eight day-use picnic areas with tables and grills, group shelters with electricity, 23 concrete camping sites including RV sites, playgrounds and a lighted boat ramp, as well as boat and fishing docks.  Electric service, water service and comfort stations with showers are all available.[2]'

name: Crowder Lake University Park
description: b'Crowder Lake University Park is a reservoir in Washita County, Oklahoma, 8 miles (13\xc2\xa0km) south of Weatherford on SH 54, 2 miles (3.2\xc2\xa0km) east and 1 mile (1.6\xc2\xa0km) south on County Road, then 0.75 miles (1.21\xc2\xa0km) west on Park Road.
