The 22 acres (8.9\xc2\xa0ha) park is on the 158 acres (64\xc2\xa0ha) Crowder Lake.[1] Once a state park, it has been owned and operated by Southwestern Oklahoma State University (SWOSU) since 2003.'

name: Dripping Springs Park
description: b'For the waterfall & park in Delaware County, Oklahoma known until 1990 as Dripping Springs, see Natural Falls State Park.'

name: Heavener Runestone Park
description: b'Heavener Runestone Park is a 55-acre (220,000\xc2\xa0m2) park located in Le Flore County, Oklahoma. It is located near the city of Heavener, Oklahoma.[1] Formerly a state park of Oklahoma, it was transferred to the City of Heavener in 2011, and is now operated by the Friends of Heavener Runestone, a non-profit organization. The Festival held at the park on two weekends a year serves as a fundraiser for operating and maintaining the park.'

name: Hochatown State Park
description: b'Hochatown State Park was once an independent Oklahoma state park in far-southeastern Oklahoma, north of the city of Broken Bow.  It was combined into Beavers Bend State Park in 2017. It is a popular destination for tourists from Oklahoma and Texas interested in camping or boating on Broken Bow Lake.'

name: Lake Eucha Park
description: b'Lake Eucha Park is a 31-acre (13\xc2\xa0ha) former Oklahoma state park located in Delaware County, Oklahoma. It is now owned and managed by the city of Tulsa, and the closest town is Jay, Oklahoma.  The park was previously known as Lake Eucha State Park and Upper Spavinaw State Park.  There have been parks, state and otherwise, around the lake since at least 1938; the oldest lease clearly applying to this park was started in 1967.[2][3]'

name: Okmulgee Park
description: b'Okmulgee Park is a city park in Okmulgee, Oklahoma in the United States.  The park contains 1,075 acres (435\xc2\xa0ha) and sits at an elevation of 758 feet (231\xc2\xa0m).[1] The park is adjacent to Dripping Springs Park and is located on Okmulgee Lake. Okmulgee Park, a municipal park established in 1963, is open for year-round recreation including camping, fishing, swimming and hiking.[2]'

name: Red Rock Canyon State Park (Oklahoma)
description: b'Red Rock Canyon Park is located 1 mile (1.6\xc2\xa0km) south of Hinton in Caddo County, Oklahoma.[2] Before the settlement of Oklahoma, the area was used by Plains Indians as a winter campsite.[3] The canyon was a stop on the California Road where settlers would gather fresh water and repair their wagons.[3][4] Wagon wheel ruts are still visible in the park.[4] The canyon has the only remaining site of native Caddo maple trees.[3]'

name: Lake Hudson (Oklahoma)
description: b'Lake Hudson, also known as Markham Ferry Reservoir, is a man-made reservoir in Mayes County, Oklahoma, United States, about 2 miles (3.2\xc2\xa0km) northwest of Locust Grove, Oklahoma and 8 miles (13\xc2\xa0km) southeast of Pryor, Oklahoma.[1] It was created by the completion of the Robert S. Kerr Dam on the Grand River in 1964. It is managed by the Grand River Dam Authority (GRDA).[2]'

name: Osage County, Oklahoma
description: b'Osage County is the largest county by area in the U.S. state of Oklahoma. Created in 1907 when Oklahoma was admitted as a state, the county is named for and is home to the federally recognized Osage Nation. The county is coextensive with the Osage Nation Reservation, established by treaty in the 19th century when the Osage relocated there from Kansas. The county seat is in Pawhuska, one of the first three towns established in the county. The total population of the county is 47,987.'

name: Wah-Sha-She Park
description: b'Wah-Sha-She Park, formerly named Wah-Sha-She State Park, is on the shore of Hulah Lake in Osage County, Oklahoma. The 266-acre (108\xc2\xa0ha) park offers recreational activities including boating, fishing, swimming and camping. Hunting is allowed in the adjacent 8,900-acre (3,600\xc2\xa0ha) Wildlife Management Area. There is also a 2,000-acre (810\xc2\xa0ha) Waterfowl Refuge where birdwatching is allowed.[2][3]'

name: Goose Lake State Recreation Area
description: b'Goose Lake State Recreation Area is located on Stateline Road, between New Pine Creek, Oregon and Goose Lake in Lake County, Oregon, on the east side of Goose Lake on the Oregon\xe2\x80\x93California border.[1]'

name: Frenchglen Hotel State Heritage Site
description: b"The Frenchglen Hotel State Heritage Site is a hotel in the sparsely populated southeast part of Oregon, United States. It is located in the unincorporated community of Frenchglen, near the base of Steens Mountain and at the northern end of the loop road that ascends almost to the mountain's summit above 9,000 feet (2,700\xc2\xa0m)."

name: Ontario State Recreation Site
description: b'Ontario State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Farewell Bend State Recreation Area
description: b'Farewell Bend State Recreation Area is a state park in Baker County, Oregon, United States, about 25 miles (40\xc2\xa0km) northwest of Ontario.  Farewell Bend was the last stop on the Oregon Trail along the Snake River where travelers could rest and water and graze their animals before the trail turned north through more rugged country to follow the Burnt River.'

name: Unity Forest State Scenic Corridor
description: b'Unity Forest State Scenic Corridor is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Unity Lake State Recreation Site
description: b'Unity Lake State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Clyde Holliday State Recreation Site
description: b'The Clyde Holliday State Recreation Site, part of the system of state parks managed by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, offers seasonal camping opportunities in a wooded tract along the John Day River near Mount Vernon. The park lies between U.S. Route 26 and the river and is 8 miles (13\xc2\xa0km) west of the city of John Day.[3]'

name: Succor Creek State Natural Area
description: b'Succor Creek State Natural Area is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Lake Owyhee State Park
description: b'Lake Owyhee State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. Bighorn sheep can be found here.'

name: Catherine Creek State Park
description: b'Catherine Creek State Park is a state park along Catherine Creek in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Hat Rock State Park
description: b'Hat Rock State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. The park is located off the east side of U.S. Highway 730 in Hermiston,[2] on the south shore of Lake Wallula behind McNary Dam on the Columbia River.[3]'

name: Hilgard Junction State Recreation Area
description: b'Hilgard Junction State Recreation Area is a state park in Hilgard, Oregon, United States, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. Located along the Grande Ronde River next to Interstate 84 at its intersection with Highway 244, the park has Full RV hook-up sites and tent camp sites with flush toilets and showers nearby.[2]'

name: Red Bridge State Wayside
description: b'Red Bridge State Wayside is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Ukiah–Dale Forest State Scenic Corridor
description: b'Ukiah\xe2\x80\x93Dale Forest State Scenic Corridor is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Emigrant Springs State Heritage Area
description: b'Emigrant Springs State Heritage Area is a state park located in central Umatilla County, Oregon, United States, approximately 15\xc2\xa0mi (24\xc2\xa0km) southeast of Pendleton. Located in old growth forest near the summit of the Blue Mountains along Interstate 84, the park was the location of a well-used campsite by emigrants along the Oregon Trail in the middle 19th century.'

name: Wallowa Lake Highway Forest State Scenic Corridor
description: b'Wallowa Lake Highway Forest State Scenic Corridor is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Wallowa River Rest Area
description: b'Wallowa River Rest Area is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Minam State Recreation Area
description: b'Minam State Recreation Area is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon. Administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, it covers about 600 acres (240\xc2\xa0ha) along the Wallowa River north of La Grande in Wallowa County. The park is off Oregon Route 82 about 15 miles (24\xc2\xa0km) northeast of Elgin.[2]'

name: Wallowa Lake State Park
description: b'Wallowa Lake State Park is a state park located in northeast Oregon in the United States.  It is at the southern shore of Wallowa Lake, near the city of Joseph in Wallowa County. The town of Wallowa Lake is situated next to the park.'

name: Iwetemlaykin State Heritage Site
description: b'Iwetemlaykin State Heritage Site, a public park in the U.S. state of Oregon, is on the south edge of Joseph, along Oregon Route 351. Its name comes from the Nez Perce place name, Iwetemlaykin (pronounced ee-weh-TEMM-lye-kinn), which means "at the edge of the lake". The park, near Wallowa Lake, is adjacent to one of the 38 sites of the Nez Perce National Historical Park, the site of the Old Chief Joseph grave and cemetery.[1]'

name: Casey State Recreation Site
description: b'Casey State Recreation Site is a day-use only state park located 29 miles northeast of Medford, Oregon off Oregon Route 62.[1] The parks offers picnic and boating facilities, as well as access to the Rogue River. It is located on the Crater Lake Highway and is a popular salmon fishing area.'

name: Prospect State Scenic Viewpoint
description: b'Prospect State Scenic Viewpoint, is a state park south of the community of Prospect on Oregon Route 62 in Jackson County, in the U.S. state of Oregon. It was formerly known as Mill Creek Falls Scenic Area, a private hiking area that was developed by Willamette Industries along the Rogue River.  Both Mill Creek Falls and Pearsony Falls are contained within the area, with Barr Creek Falls close by.[2]'

name: Joseph H. Stewart State Recreation Area
description: b'Joseph H. Stewart State Recreation Area is a state park located  on the Rogue River approximately 40 miles (64\xc2\xa0km) from Crater Lake National Park and 35 miles (56\xc2\xa0km) northeast of Medford in Jackson County, southern Oregon. It is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. Campsites are provided overlooking the  Lost Creek Reservoir.[2]'

name: The Cove Palisades State Park
description: b'The Cove Palisades State Park is a state park in eastern Jefferson County, Oregon, near Culver and Madras in the central part of the state, and is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.  It is located on the waters and surrounding lands of Lake Billy Chinook, an impoundment of the Crooked, Deschutes, and Metolius rivers.'

name: Prineville Reservoir
description: b'The Prineville Reservoir is in the high desert hills of Central Oregon, Oregon, United States.[1][2] The reservoir is on the Crooked River 14 miles (22.5\xc2\xa0km) southeast of Prineville, and 29 miles (46.7\xc2\xa0km) east of Bend. This reservoir is a popular retreat for most of Central Oregon. It is near the geographic center of Oregon. Prineville Reservoir State Park is managed by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Prineville Reservoir
description: b'The Prineville Reservoir is in the high desert hills of Central Oregon, Oregon, United States.[1][2] The reservoir is on the Crooked River 14 miles (22.5\xc2\xa0km) southeast of Prineville, and 29 miles (46.7\xc2\xa0km) east of Bend. This reservoir is a popular retreat for most of Central Oregon. It is near the geographic center of Oregon. Prineville Reservoir State Park is managed by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Deschutes River State Recreation Area
description: b'The Deschutes River State Recreation Area is a park at the confluence of the Deschutes and Columbia rivers in the U.S. state of Oregon. It is a few miles east of The Dalles. The 35.1-acre (14.2\xc2\xa0ha) park offers opportunities for camping, fishing, hiking, mountain biking, and equestrian trail riding.'

name: White River Falls State Park
description: b'White River Falls State Park is a state park in north central Oregon. It is located 35 miles (56\xc2\xa0km) by road south of The Dalles and 4.5 miles (7.2\xc2\xa0km) east of Tygh Valley.'

name: Deschutes River State Recreation Area
description: b'The Deschutes River State Recreation Area is a park at the confluence of the Deschutes and Columbia rivers in the U.S. state of Oregon. It is a few miles east of The Dalles. The 35.1-acre (14.2\xc2\xa0ha) park offers opportunities for camping, fishing, hiking, mountain biking, and equestrian trail riding.'

name: Cline Falls State Scenic Viewpoint
description: b'Cline Falls State Scenic Viewpoint (also known as Cline Falls State Park) is a state park near Redmond, Oregon, United States.  It is located on the Deschutes River.  The park covers 9 acres (36,000\xc2\xa0m2).  It is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Fort Rock
description: b"Fort Rock is a tuff ring located on an ice age lake bed in north Lake County, Oregon, United States.[3]\nThe ring is about 4,460 feet (1,360\xc2\xa0m) in diameter and stands about 200 feet (60\xc2\xa0m) high above the surrounding plain.[4] Its name is derived from the tall, straight sides that resemble the palisades of a fort. The region of Fort Rock-Christmas Lake Valley Basin contains about 40 such tuff rings and maars and is located in the Brothers Fault Zone of central Oregon's Great Basin. William Sullivan, an early settler in the area, named Fort Rock in 1873 while searching for lost cattle.[5][6]"

name: La Pine State Park
description: b'La Pine State Park is a state park along the Deschutes River in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Pilot Butte (Oregon)
description: b'Pilot Butte is a lava dome that was created from an extinct volcano located in Bend, Oregon.  It is a cinder cone butte which rises nearly 500 feet (150\xc2\xa0m) above the surrounding plains. Bend is one of four cities in the United States to have a volcano within its boundaries. Portland, with Mount Tabor, is the only other city in Oregon with a volcano within its city limits. Jackson Volcano in Jackson, Mississippi, and Diamond Head in Honolulu are the others.'

name: Peter Skene Ogden State Scenic Viewpoint
description: b'The Peter Skene Ogden State Scenic Viewpoint is a state park on the Crooked River in Oregon, United States. It is on the border of Deschutes and Jefferson counties.'

name: Smith Rock State Park
description: b"Smith Rock State Park is a state park located in central Oregon's High Desert near the communities of Redmond and Terrebonne. The day-use area of the park is open daily from dawn to dusk. The park also has a camping area as well that accommodates tent camping only. Its sheer cliffs of tuff and basalt are ideal for rock climbing of all difficulty levels. Smith Rock is generally considered the birthplace of modern American sport climbing, and is host to cutting-edge climbing routes. It is popular for sport climbing, traditional climbing, multi-pitch climbing, and bouldering."

name: Booth State Scenic Corridor
description: b'Booth State Scenic Corridor (also known as Booth State Wayside or Booth State Park) is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Geisel Monument State Heritage Site
description: b'Geisel Monument State Heritage Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Humbug Mountain State Park
description: b'Humbug Mountain State Park is a state park located on the Oregon coast. It is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. The park can be accessed via the US Route 101, 6 miles (10\xc2\xa0km) south of Port Orford, and 28 miles (45\xc2\xa0km) north of Gold Beach.[2] \nIt covers 1,842 acres (7.45\xc2\xa0km2) of land around 1,759-foot (536\xc2\xa0m) Humbug Mountain, one of the tallest headlands on the Oregon coast.[2][3]'

name: Otter Point State Recreation Site
description: b'Otter Point State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Paradise Point State Recreation Site
description: b'Paradise Point State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Port Orford Heads State Park
description: b'Port Orford Heads State Park is a coastal state park in northwest Curry County, Oregon, United States, in the city of Port Orford.  Established in 1976, it is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Cape Blanco (Oregon)
description: b'Cape Blanco is a prominent headland on the Pacific Ocean coast of southwestern Oregon in the United States, forming the westernmost point in the state.[3] Cape Blanco extends further west than any point of land in the contiguous United States (lower 48 states) except portions of the Olympic Peninsula in Washington, including Cape Alava, the true westernmost point.[4] The cape is part of Cape Blanco State Park and is the location of the Cape Blanco Light, first lit in 1870.[3]'

name: Bandon State Natural Area
description: b'Bandon State Natural Area is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon. It is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. The 879-acre (356\xc2\xa0ha) park lies west of U.S. Route 101, off Beach Loop Drive, about 5 miles (8\xc2\xa0km) south of Bandon.[2][3] The Oregon Coast Trail passes through the park.[3]'

name: Coquille Myrtle Grove State Natural Site
description: b'Coquille Myrtle Grove State Natural Site is a state park administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department in the U.S. state of Oregon. The park, bordering the Powers Highway (Oregon Route 542) between Myrtle Point and Powers, in Coos County, features a swimming hole and sandy beach along the South Fork Coquille River. Other amenities include parking, picnic tables, restrooms, and access to fishing but no drinking water.[3]'

name: Face Rock State Scenic Viewpoint
description: b'Face Rock State Scenic Viewpoint is a state park in Bandon, Oregon, United States, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. The rocks and tidal flats adjacent to the park form part of the Oregon Islands National Wildlife Refuge.[2] More than 300 species of birds frequent the area.[3]'

name: Hoffman Memorial State Wayside
description: b'Hoffman Memorial State Wayside is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Seven Devils State Recreation Site
description: b'Seven Devils State Recreation Site is a state park and beach in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Bullards Beach State Park
description: b'Bullards Beach State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Alfred A. Loeb State Park
description: b'Alfred A. Loeb State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. Located on the banks of the Chetco River, the park offers camping, hiking, fishing, swimming, and rafting opportunities. In the parks boundaries are 3 rental cabins, 53 camping sites, a launch area for drift boats, a day-use area, and the head of a 0.75-mile (1.2\xc2\xa0km) trail that the official Web site says leads to northernmost coastal redwood grove in the United States.'

name: Cape Sebastian State Scenic Corridor
description: b'Cape Sebastian State Scenic Corridor is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Crissey Field State Recreation Site
description: b'Crissey Field State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. It is the south-westernmost point in the state of Oregon.'

name: McVay Rock State Recreation Site
description: b'McVay Rock State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Pistol River State Scenic Viewpoint
description: b'Pistol River State Scenic Viewpoint is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Samuel H. Boardman State Scenic Corridor
description: b'Samuel H. Boardman State Scenic Corridor is a linear state park in southwestern Oregon, in the United States. It is 12 miles (19\xc2\xa0km) long and thickly forested along steep and rugged coastline with a few small sand beaches. It is named in honor of Samuel H. Boardman, the first Oregon Parks superintendent.[2]'

name: Winchuck State Recreation Site
description: b'Winchuck State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Harris Beach State Park
description: b'Harris Beach State Park is an Oregon State Park located on US Highway 101, north of Brookings.  The day-use area offers a restroom and picnic area with tables, and the campground has RV sites, yurts and tent sites available year-round.[2]'

name: Alderwood State Wayside
description: b'Alderwood State Wayside is a state park on Oregon Route 36 in the U.S. state of Oregon. Administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, the day-use wayside covers about 76 acres (31\xc2\xa0ha).[2] It is open year-round and attracts about 45,000 visitors annually.[2]'

name: Elijah Bristow State Park
description: b'Elijah Bristow State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. It has more than 10 miles (16\xc2\xa0km) of well-maintained trails along ponds, wetlands, meadows, and the Middle Fork Willamette River, and through forests of broadleaf and evergreen trees. The trails are open to horses, hikers, and mountain bikers, and there is a separate equestrian staging area popular with riding clubs.[2]'

name: Washburne State Wayside
description: b'Washburne State Wayside is a state park 4 miles (6\xc2\xa0km) northwest of Junction City, in the U.S. state of Oregon.[3] Administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, the wayside serves as a rest stop for travelers on Oregon Route 99W and interpretive center for the Applegate Trail.[4] The state bought the land for the park in 1926 from William C. and Mae E. Washburne.[2] It lies on the border between Lane and Benton counties.[4]'

name: Maples Rest Area
description: b'Maples Rest Area is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Mongold Day-Use Area
description: b"Mongold Day-Use Area is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.  It is located on Oregon Route 22 about 3.5 miles (5.6\xc2\xa0km) west of the town of Detroit, Oregon.  Because it is on the north shore of Detroit Lake, it is administered as part of Detroit Lake State Park, even though it is about 1.5 miles (2.4\xc2\xa0km) west of the park's boundary."

name: North Santiam State Recreation Area
description: b'North Santiam State Recreation Area is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Detroit Lake
description: b'Detroit Lake is a reservoir impounded by the Detroit Dam on the North Santiam River 46 miles (74\xc2\xa0km) southeast of Salem, Oregon, United States.[1][2]\nThe lake is adjacent to Oregon Route 22 near the city of Detroit.\nThis mesotrophic lake stores water for use by the city of Salem and other nearby communities.'

name: Cape Arago State Park
description: b'Cape Arago State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.  Cape Arago is north of  Bandon and 15 miles southwest of  Coos Bay on Cape Arago Highway in  Coos County.'

name: Golden and Silver Falls State Natural Area
description: b'Golden and Silver Falls State Natural Area is a state park in Coos County, Oregon, United States, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. The nearest settlement is Allegany.'

name: Shore Acres State Park
description: b'Shore Acres State Park is a state park 13 miles (21\xc2\xa0km) south of Coos Bay in the U.S. state of Oregon.[1] It is one of three state parks along the Cape Arago Highway, which runs along the Pacific Ocean west of U.S. Route 101. Sunset Bay State Park is about 1 mile (1.6\xc2\xa0km) north of Shore Acres, and Cape Arago State Park is about a mile south.[3]'

name: William M. Tugman State Park
description: b'William M. Tugman State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon. Administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department (OPRD), the park borders Eel Lake, about 8 miles (13\xc2\xa0km) south of Reedsport near U.S. Route 101.[3]'

name: Sunset Bay State Park
description: b'Sunset Bay State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon. Administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, it is about 0.4 miles (0.6\xc2\xa0km) south of Cape Arago Lighthouse and 2.5 miles (4.0\xc2\xa0km) outside the town of Charleston on Coos Bay. The park offers a crescent shaped beach, tide pools, hiking trails and a year-round campground.[3]'

name: Illinois River Forks State Park
description: b'Illinois River Forks State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.  The park consists of approximately 400 acres, with 170 located between the forks of the Illinois River and the remainder on the west side.  The portion between the forks of the river and accessed from Highway 199 just south of Cave Junction, is developed with paved parking, grass lawns with picnic tables, outhouses, and offers a wonderful swimming hole for summer users.  The west side of the park, accessed from Westside Road, offers the West Side Trailhead and nearly seven miles of single-track, natural surface hiking and equestrian trails.  There is gravelled parking for cars, and a separate pull-through parking lane area for horse rigs.  A vault toilet and kiosk with the trail system displayed is in the parking area.'

name: TouVelle State Recreation Site
description: b'TouVelle State Recreation Site is a state park, administered  by Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, and located in Jackson County, Oregon, United States, 9 miles (14\xc2\xa0km) north of Medford, where Table Rock Road crosses the Rogue River.  This 51-acre (210,000\xc2\xa0m2) park is used for fishing, birding, hiking (in the adjacent Denman Wildlife Area), picnicking and swimming.  There is also a boat ramp, which lies at the lower end of an easily navigated stretch of the Rogue.  A daily user-fee  or annual permit is required.'

name: Tub Springs State Wayside
description: b'Tub Springs State Wayside is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Wolf Creek Inn State Heritage Site
description: b'Wolf Creek Inn State Heritage Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Valley of the Rogue State Park
description: b'Valley of the Rogue State Park is a state park in west central Jackson County, Oregon, near Grants Pass and Medford, and is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.  It lies along the banks of the Rogue River, adjacent to Interstate 5.[3]  The park offers a year-round, full-service campground, a nature trail, a day-use area, and river access for boating, fishing, and swimming.'

name: Bald Peak State Scenic Viewpoint
description: b'Bald Peak State Scenic Viewpoint is a state park located atop Bald Peak located in Yamhill County, in the United States. The day use only park offers picnic tables and a hiking trail for views of the Willamette Valley and the Cascade Range. The state of Oregon acquired the 26 acres (11\xc2\xa0ha) in 1931 after Yamhill and Washington counties requested a park from the state.'

name: Molalla River State Park
description: b'The Molalla River State Park is located in U.S. state of Oregon. It is a few miles north of Canby, and half a mile from the Canby Ferry. The park is south of the Willamette River and east of the Molalla River, at the confluence of the Pudding, Molalla and Willamette rivers.  The Pudding River flows into the Molalla from the west, just before the Molalla joins the Willamette.  The floodplains of these rivers provide important habitat for waterfowl, wading birds, deer, small mammals, reptiles and amphibians. A blue heron rookery, one of the largest in the Willamette Valley, is located in Molalla River State Park.'

name: Champoeg, Oregon
description: b'Champoeg (/\xca\x83\xc3\xa6m\xcb\x88pu\xcb\x90i\xcb\x90/ sham-POO-ee, historically /\xca\x83\xc3\xa6m\xcb\x88pu\xcb\x90\xc9\x9b\xc9\xa1/ sham-POO-eg[1]) is a former town in the U.S. state of Oregon. Now a ghost town, it was an important settlement in the Willamette Valley in the early 1840s. Located halfway between Oregon City and Salem, it was the site of the first provisional government of the Oregon Country.'

name: Beaver Creek State Natural Area
description: b'Beaver Creek State Natural Area is a state park in Lincoln County, Oregon, United States, that opened to the public on October\xc2\xa01, 2010.[1] It is located near Ona Beach State Park, about 8 miles (13\xc2\xa0km) south of Newport.'

name: Bolon Island Tideways State Scenic Corridor
description: b"Bolon Island Tideways State Scenic Corridor is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. The 11.4-acre (4.6\xc2\xa0ha) park is on Bolon Island 10 river miles (16\xc2\xa0km) from the mouth of the Umpqua River and north of Reedsport. It is along Highway 101 and near the site, where in 1828, most of Jedediah Smith's party were massacred. The land was given to the state in 1934 by William C. and Jennie D. Chamberlain.[2]"

name: Darlingtonia State Natural Site
description: b'Darlingtonia State Natural Site (18 acres) is a state park and botanical preserve located five miles (8\xc2\xa0km) north of Florence, Oregon, United States on U.S. Route 101, just west of Mercer Lake and south of Sutton Lake that is dedicated to the preservation of a rare plant.'

name: Governor Patterson Memorial State Recreation Site
description: b'Governor Patterson Memorial State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Umpqua River Light
description: b'The Umpqua River Light is a lighthouse on the Oregon Coast of the United States, located at the mouth of the Umpqua River on Winchester Bay, in Douglas County, Oregon.'

name: Beachside State Recreation Site
description: b'Beachside State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Carl G. Washburne Memorial State Park
description: b'Carl G. Washburne Memorial State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. This park is in Lane County near Florence and Yachats. Very Scenic wide beach, great for dogs, kids, kites. Some areas nearby are SNOWY PLOVER protected breeding areas, where dogs are banned, so be careful to keep dogs leashed if uncertain, and always in the State Park itself.'

name: Heceta Head Light
description: b'Heceta Head Light is a lighthouse on the Oregon Coast 13 miles (21\xc2\xa0km) north of Florence, and 13 miles (21\xc2\xa0km) south of Yachats in the United States. It is located at Heceta Head Lighthouse State Scenic Viewpoint, a state park, midway up a 205-foot-tall (62\xc2\xa0m) headland. Built in 1894, the 56-foot (17\xc2\xa0m)-tall lighthouse shines a beam visible for 21 nautical miles (39\xc2\xa0km; 24\xc2\xa0mi), making it the strongest light on the Oregon Coast.[2]'

name: Muriel O. Ponsler Memorial State Scenic Viewpoint
description: b'Muriel O. Ponsler Memorial State Scenic Viewpoint is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Neptune State Scenic Viewpoint
description: b'Neptune State Scenic Viewpoint is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Smelt Sands State Recreation Site
description: b'Smelt Sands State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Tokatee Klootchman State Natural Site
description: b'Tokatee Klootchman State Natural Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon. Administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, it offers wildlife, bird, and marine-mammal watching, and it has a beach. The park is 16 miles (26\xc2\xa0km) north of Florence on U.S. Route 101.[2]'

name: Stonefield Beach State Recreation Site
description: b'Stonefield Beach State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: W. B. Nelson State Recreation Site
description: b'W. B. Nelson State Recreation Site is a state park in Lincoln County, western Oregon.'

name: Yachats Ocean Road State Natural Site
description: b'The Yachats Ocean Road State Natural Site is a state park in southern Lincoln County, Oregon, in the town of Yachats.  It is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.  It is located on the Pacific Ocean coast, adjacent to the Oregon Coast Highway and the mouth of the Yachats River.  The park is open for day use only, and offers scenic driving on a 1-mile (1.6\xc2\xa0km) loop, and wildlife and surf viewing, but is backed on its landward side by low-intensity urban development.'

name: Yachats State Recreation Area
description: b'The Yachats State Recreation Area is a state park in southern Lincoln County, Oregon, in the central district of the town of Yachats.  It is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.  It is located on the Pacific Ocean coast, on the north side of the mouth of the Yachats River.  The park is open for day use only, and offers wildlife and surf viewing, tidepools, fishing, and picnicking.'

name: Jessie M. Honeyman Memorial State Park
description: b'Jessie M. Honeyman Memorial State Park, also known simply as Honeyman State Park, is in Lane County of the U.S. state of Oregon. It lies 3 miles (5\xc2\xa0km) south of Florence along Highway 101, the coastal highway. The 27,212-acre (11,012\xc2\xa0ha) Oregon Dunes National Recreation Area adjoins the park to the west. Many amenities are available, including over 200 campsites,[3] all-terrain vehicle access, swimming, fishing and sandboarding.[4]'

name: Erratic Rock State Natural Site
description: b'Erratic Rock State Natural Site is a state park in the Willamette Valley of Oregon, United States. Featuring a 40-short-ton (36\xc2\xa0t) glacial erratic from the Missoula Floods, the small park sits atop a foothill of the Northern Oregon Coast Range in Yamhill County between Sheridan and McMinnville off Oregon Route 18. The day use only park is owned and maintained by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Holman State Wayside
description: b'Holman State Wayside is a state park in Polk County, Oregon, United States, on Oregon Route 22 at the foot of the Eola Hills near the community of Eola. The wayside is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department but was closed to vehicular traffic in 2007 because of ongoing problems with criminal activity.[2]'

name: Maud Williamson State Recreation Site
description: b'Maud Williamson State Recreation Site is a state park in Yamhill County, Oregon, United States, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. The park is located at the intersection of Oregon Route 221 and Oregon Route 153 near Wheatland. The park entrance is across from Wheatland Road, which leads to the Wheatland Ferry.[2]'

name: Sarah Helmick State Recreation Site
description: b'Sarah Helmick State Recreation Site, also known as Helmick Park, is a state park located south of Monmouth, in Polk County, Oregon, United States. It is located on the floodplain of the Luckiamute River and is forested by Bigleaf Maple, Douglas-fir, and Black Cottonwood trees, among other varieties. The park is named for Sarah Helmick, a pioneer to Oregon in 1845 who donated the original land.'

name: Willamette Mission State Park
description: b'Willamette Mission State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, located about four miles (6\xc2\xa0km) north of Keizer adjacent to the Wheatland Ferry and east of the Willamette River.  It includes Willamette Station Site, Methodist Mission in Oregon, which is listed by the National Register of Historic Places.[1][5]'

name: Bonnie Lure State Recreation Area
description: b'Bonnie Lure State Recreation Area is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Mary S. Young State Recreation Area
description: b'Mary S. Young Park is a city park in the U.S. state of Oregon.  It is located within the city of West Linn, alongside the Willamette River, and is heavily wooded.  It offers more than five miles of hiking trails, bicycle trails, picnicking, bird watching, fishing, sports fields, and a very popular dog off-leash area.'

name: Milo McIver State Park
description: b'Milo McIver State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon. It is in Clackamas County along the Clackamas River, near Estacada and close to Mount Hood.'

name: Tryon Creek State Natural Area
description: b'The Tryon Creek State Natural Area is a state park located primarily in Portland, in the U.S. state of Oregon. It is the only Oregon state park within a major metropolitan area.[1]   The 645-acre (261\xc2\xa0ha) park lies between Boones Ferry Road and Terwilliger Boulevard in southwest Portland in Multnomah County and northern Lake Oswego in Clackamas County and is bisected from north to south by Tryon Creek.'

name: Banks–Vernonia State Trail
description: b'The Banks\xe2\x80\x93Vernonia State Trail is a paved rail trail and state park in northwest Oregon in the United States. It runs for 21 miles (34\xc2\xa0km), primarily north\xe2\x80\x93south, between the towns of Vernonia in Columbia County and Banks in Washington County on an abandoned railroad bed.[2] Banks is about 25 miles (40\xc2\xa0km) west of Portland.'

name: Ainsworth State Park
description: b'Ainsworth State Park is a state park in eastern Multnomah County, Oregon, near Cascade Locks.  It is located in the Columbia River Gorge, adjacent to the Historic Columbia River Highway.  The park  administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, offers a seasonal, full-service campground, access to Gorge hiking trails beyond park boundaries, and a day-use area.'

name: Benson State Recreation Area
description: b'Benson State Recreation Area is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Bridal Veil Falls (Oregon)
description: b'Bridal Veil Falls is a waterfall located on Bridal Veil Creek in the Columbia River Gorge in Multnomah County, Oregon, United States.'

name: Crown Point (Oregon)
description: b"Crown Point (also known historically as Thor's Heights or Thor's Crown)[1][2] is a basalt promontory on the Columbia River Gorge and an associated state park in the U.S. state of Oregon. It is located in eastern Multnomah County, approximately 15 miles (24\xc2\xa0km) east of Portland. Crown Point is one of the scenic lookouts along the Historic Columbia River Highway, providing a panoramic view of part of the Columbia River.  It stands 733 feet (223\xc2\xa0m) above the river and is the remains of a lava flow that filled the ancestral channel of the Columbia River 14 to 17 million years ago.[3][4] The Point was designated a National Natural Landmark in 1971.[5]"

name: Dabney State Recreation Area
description: b'Dabney State Recreation Area is a park on the Sandy River in the U.S. state of Oregon. Located in Multnomah County outside the city of Troutdale, the park offers swimming, boating, disc golf, and other activities.'

name: George W. Joseph State Natural Area
description: b'George W. Joseph State Natural Area is a natural area in the U.S. state of Oregon. It is located near the city of Troutdale between Latourell Falls and Guy W. Talbot State Park, and is accessible from both.'

name: Guy W. Talbot State Park
description: b'Guy W. Talbot State Park is a state park in the Columbia River Gorge, near Troutdale, Oregon, United States. Although the main feature of the park is Latourell Falls, the parkland stretches west to the Crown Point State Scenic Corridor. Here the Historic Columbia River Highway descends from Crown Point via the Figure-Eight Loops, a series of horseshoe curves that "develop distance" and thus keep the grade to a minimum.'

name: John B. Yeon State Scenic Corridor
description: b'John B. Yeon State Scenic Corridor is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. It is located about 35 miles east of Portland in the Columbia Gorge. It is named in honor of John B. Yeon, one of the principal financiers of the Historic Columbia River Highway U.S. Route 30 which was constructed between 1913 and 1922. Located in the Columbia River Gorge National Scenic Area,[2] the park features hiking trails that access some of the nearby waterfalls, including Elowah Falls.'

name: Koberg Beach State Recreation Site
description: b'Koberg Beach State Recreation Site is a state park in Hood River County, Oregon United States, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. The park offers a wayside rest area for west bound traffic on Interstate 84.'

name: Lewis and Clark State Recreation Site
description: b"Lewis and Clark State Recreation Site is a state park in eastern Multnomah County, Oregon, near Troutdale and Corbett, and is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. It is located on the Sandy River, near its confluence with the Columbia River. Broughton's Bluff marks the westernmost extent of the Columbia River Gorge at the site."

name: Mayer State Park
description: b'Mayer State Park is a state park in the Columbia River Gorge, near Rowena, Oregon in Wasco County in the U.S. state of Oregon. It consists of several disjointed parcels of transected by Interstate 84 and the tracks of the Union Pacific Railroad.'

name: Memaloose State Park
description: b'Memaloose State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Chanticleer Point
description: b'Chanticleer Point is a geographical landmark on the Oregon side of the Columbia River Gorge. It is the first notable overlook encountered traveling east on the Historic Columbia River Highway. It is a typical location from which to take photos of the gorge featuring Crown Point prominently. It overlooks Rooster Rock State Park.'

name: Seneca Fouts Memorial State Natural Area
description: b'Seneca Fouts Memorial State Natural Area is a state park in northern Hood River County, Oregon, just west of the city of Hood River, and is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. It is located in the Columbia River Gorge, adjacent to an abandoned section of the Historic Columbia River Highway. This park is one of a trio encompassing areas in the vicinity of Mitchell Point, along with Vinzenz Lausmann Memorial State Natural Area and Wygant State Natural Area. The three parks offers scenic hiking and views over the Gorge.'

name: Sheridan State Scenic Corridor
description: b'Sheridan State Scenic Corridor is a state park in the Columbia River Gorge, west of Cascade Locks, Oregon. The 11-acre (4.5\xc2\xa0ha) property, containing an old-growth forest, is located on the south side of Interstate 84 at approximately milepoint 42.5,[2] and was not accessible by motor vehicle since I-84 was built in 1960. However, with the opening of the Eagle Creek-Cascade Locks segment of the Historic Columbia River Highway State Trail in 1998, it has become easily accessible by foot or bicycle.[3] The park is on a triangular lot, completely surrounded by I-84 and the Mount Hood National Forest.'

name: Starvation Creek State Park
description: b'Starvation Creek State Park is a state park located west of Hood River, Oregon in the Columbia River Gorge.  It was named Starvation Creek because a train was stopped there by snow drifts and passengers had to dig out the train.  No one starved there.[2]'

name: Viento State Park
description: b'Viento State Park is a state park in north central Hood River County, Oregon, near the city of Hood River. The park, named for the former Viento railroad station located there, is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. The park is on the south bank of the Columbia River in the Columbia River Gorge. Interstate 84 and the Union Pacific Railroad pass through the park. It offers a seasonal, full-service campground, access to gorge hiking trails beyond park boundaries, a day-use area and river access for windsurfing and kiteboarding.'

name: Vinzenz Lausmann Memorial State Natural Area
description: b'Vinzenz Lausmann Memorial State Natural Area is a state park in northern Hood River County, Oregon, 5.3 miles (8.5\xc2\xa0km) west of the city of Hood River, and is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. It is located in the Columbia River Gorge, adjacent to an abandoned section of the Historic Columbia River Highway.  This park is one of a trio encompassing areas in the vicinity of Mitchell Point, along with Seneca Fouts Memorial State Natural Area and Wygant State Natural Area.  The three parks offer scenic hiking and views over the Gorge.'

name: Wygant State Natural Area
description: b'Wygant State Natural Area is a state park in northern Hood River County, Oregon, just west of the city of Hood River, and is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. It is located in the Columbia River Gorge, adjacent to an abandoned section of the Historic Columbia River Highway.  This park is one of a trio encompassing areas in the vicinity of Mitchell Point, along with Seneca Fouts Memorial State Natural Area and Vinzenz Lausmann Memorial State Natural Area.  The three parks offers scenic hiking and views over the Gorge.'

name: Rooster Rock State Park
description: b'Rooster Rock State Park is a state park located east of Corbett, in the U.S. state of Oregon. One of the features of the park is Rooster Rock, a column of basalt forming a natural obelisk, which stands near the south side of the Columbia River Gorge, in the lee of Crown Point. The park is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Bradley State Scenic Viewpoint
description: b'Bradley State Scenic Viewpoint is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.  It is located directly north of U.S. Route 30 between Astoria and Portland.'

name: Del Rey Beach State Recreation Site
description: b'Del Rey Beach State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Fort Stevens (Oregon)
description: b'Fort Stevens was an American military installation that guarded the mouth of the Columbia River in the state of Oregon. Built near the end of the American Civil War, it was named for a slain Civil War general and former Washington Territory governor, Isaac I. Stevens. The fort was an active military reservation from 1863\xe2\x80\x931947.[2] It is now listed on the National Register of Historic Places.'

name: Cape Kiwanda State Natural Area
description: b'Cape Kiwanda State Natural Area is a state park in Pacific City, Oregon, United States. Cape Kiwanda is on the Three Capes Scenic Route, which includes Cape Meares and Cape Lookout. Hiking to the top of Cape Kiwanda allows views of Nestucca Bay to the south and Cape Lookout to the north.'

name: Cape Meares
description: b'Cape Meares is a small headland on the Pacific coast in Tillamook County, Oregon, United States. The cape forms a high steep bluff on the south end of Tillamook Bay, approximately five miles (8\xc2\xa0km) northwest of the city of Tillamook. Much of the cape is part of the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department-administered Cape Meares State Scenic Viewpoint with three miles of hiking trails, which includes the Cape Meares Lighthouse.  The cape is named after John Meares, a British explorer.'

name: Oceanside Beach State Recreation Site
description: b'Oceanside Beach State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon. Administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, the park is open to the public and is fee-free. Amenities at the site, in the unincorporated community of Oceanside, include picnicking, wildlife watching, fishing, windsurfing, and kite flying. Beachcombing is popular in summer, and agate hunting is best in winter, when ocean currents remove sand. Oceanside is about 11 miles (18\xc2\xa0km) west of Tillamook off U.S. Route 101.[2]'

name: Bob Straub State Park
description: b'Bob Straub State Park is a 484-acre (196\xc2\xa0ha)[2] state park in Pacific City, Tillamook County, Oregon, United States. It is named for former Oregon Governor Robert W. Straub.  The park encompasses the Nestucca Sand Spit and is bordered by the Pacific Ocean to the west and Nestucca River to the east.'

name: Cape Lookout State Park
description: b'Cape Lookout State Park is a state park on Cape Lookout in the U.S. state of Oregon. It is located in Tillamook County, south of the city of Tillamook, on a sand spit between Netarts Bay and the Pacific Ocean.'

name: Arcadia Beach State Recreation Site
description: b'Arcadia Beach State Recreation Site is a beach and state park on the Oregon Coast of the United States located two miles south of Cannon Beach. Under the right conditions, one may hear the "singing sands" a squeaking or violin-like noise.[2]'

name: Ecola State Park
description: b'Ecola State Park is a state park located approximately 3 miles north of Cannon Beach in Clatsop County in the U.S. state of Oregon on the Oregon Coast. It is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.[2]'

name: Golden, Oregon
description: b'Golden is an abandoned mining town located \nat Coyote Creek in Josephine County, Oregon, United States.'

name: Hug Point State Recreation Site
description: b'Hug Point State Recreation Site is a state park on the northern Oregon Coast in the U.S. state of Oregon.[2] Administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, the park is open to the public and is fee-free. Amenities at the park, which is 5 miles (8.0\xc2\xa0km) south of Cannon Beach along U.S. Route 101, include picnicking, fishing, and a Pacific Ocean beach.[1]'

name: Manhattan Beach State Recreation Site
description: b'Manhattan Beach State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon. Administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, the park is open to the public and is fee-free. Amenities at the park, which is 2 miles (3\xc2\xa0km) north of Rockaway Beach along U.S. Route 101, include picnicking, fishing, and a Pacific Ocean beach.[2]'

name: Oswald West State Park
description: b'Oswald West State Park is part of the state park system of the U.S. state of Oregon. It is located about 10 miles (16\xc2\xa0km) south of the city of Cannon Beach, adjacent to Arch Cape, on the Pacific Ocean. The park covers 2,448 acres (9.91\xc2\xa0km2), with many miles of hiking trails both inside the park grounds and linking to other parks and landmarks beyond.'

name: Saddle Mountain State Natural Area
description: b'Saddle Mountain State Natural Area is a state park in northwest Oregon. It is located in the Northern Oregon Coast Range in central Clatsop County, about 20 miles (32\xc2\xa0km) by road from Seaside. A 2.5-mile (4.0\xc2\xa0km) long hiking trail climbs to the top of Saddle Mountain, which is located in the park. On clear days, the Pacific Ocean, Columbia River mouth and several of the Cascade mountains in Washington and Oregon can be seen from the summit.[2]'

name: Tolovana Beach State Recreation Site
description: b'Tolovana Beach State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Nehalem Bay State Park
description: b'Nehalem Bay State Park is a state park in the United States located on the Oregon Coast, near the communities of Nehalem and Manzanita on the Nehalem Spit, a sand spit west of Nehalem Bay.[2]'

name: Alsea Bay Historic Interpretive Center
description: b'Alsea Bay Historic Interpretive Center is a public facility in Waldport, Oregon, administered and owned by the city of Waldport. It is adjacent to the Alsea Bay Bridge and was constructed by the Oregon Department of Transportation as part of the bridge replacement project. It was transferred to the city on Oct 8th, 2020 from the Oregon Department of Transportation.'

name: Driftwood Beach State Recreation Site
description: b'Driftwood Beach State Recreation Site is a state park administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department in the U.S. state of Oregon. Located 3 miles (5\xc2\xa0km) north of Waldport along the Pacific Ocean, the park offers beach access, picnicking, and fishing in a setting of shore\xc2\xa0pines and sand. It is fee-free and open year-round.[2]'

name: Lost Creek State Recreation Site
description: b'Lost Creek State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Brian Booth State Park
description: b'Brian Booth State Park is a coastal recreational area located near Seal Rock, Oregon. It consists of two major portions: Ona Beach State Park and Beaver Creek State Natural Area. The park has beach access, kayaking, and hiking trails. The park is 886.32 acres and has an annual attendance of 247,772 people. Ona is known as a Chinook Jargon word for razor clam.[2]'

name: Seal Rock State Recreation Site
description: b'Seal Rock State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Yaquina Bay State Recreation Site
description: b"Yaquina Bay State Recreation Site, established in 1948, is a coastal state park in west-central Lincoln County, Oregon, United States, in the city of Newport.  It is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, and located at the north end of Yaquina Bay near its outlet to the Pacific Ocean.  The site includes picnic facilities, beach access, a fisherman's memorial shrine, a forested bluff and the historic Yaquina Bay Lighthouse."

name: South Beach State Park
description: b'South Beach State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. It is near the unincorporated community of South Beach.'

name: Cascadia State Park
description: b'Cascadia State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon near Sweet Home along the South Santiam River at Cascadia. The park includes a day use area, campsites, hiking trails and 150 foot Lower Soda Creek Falls.[2]'

name: Silver Falls State Park
description: b'Silver Falls State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, located near Silverton, about 20 miles (32\xc2\xa0km) east-southeast of Salem.  It is the largest state park in Oregon with an area of more than 9,000 acres (36\xc2\xa0km2), and it includes more than 24 miles (39\xc2\xa0km) of walking trails, 14 miles (23\xc2\xa0km) of horse trails, and a 4-mile (6.4\xc2\xa0km) bike path. Its 8.7-mile (14.0\xc2\xa0km) Canyon Trail/Trail of Ten Falls runs along the banks of Silver Creek and by ten waterfalls, from which the park received its name. Four of the ten falls have an amphitheater-like surrounding that allows the trail to pass behind the flow of the falls.[2] The Silver Falls State Park Concession Building Area and the Silver Creek Youth Camp-Silver Falls State Park are separately listed on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places.'

name: Agate Beach State Recreation Site
description: b'Agate Beach State Recreation Site is a state park between Newport and Agate Beach in Lincoln County in the U.S. state of Oregon. It is administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.[2]'

name: Boiler Bay State Scenic Viewpoint
description: b'Boiler Bay State Scenic Viewpoint is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. The park is one mile (1.6\xc2\xa0km) north of Depoe Bay, Oregon.'

name: D River State Recreation Site
description: b"D River State Recreation Site (also D River State Wayside[2] and D River State Park[1]) is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.  It is a sandy beach of the Pacific Ocean within central Lincoln City along the length of the 120-foot (37\xc2\xa0m) long D River, one of the world's shortest rivers."

name: Devils Lake State Recreation Area
description: b'Devils Lake State Recreation Area (also Devils Lake State Park[1]) is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Devils Punch Bowl State Natural Area
description: b'Devils Punch Bowl State Natural Area is a state day use park on the central Oregon Coast in the United States.  It is centered on a large bowl naturally carved in a rock headland which is partially open to the Pacific Ocean.  Waves enter the bowl and often violently churn, swirl, and foam.[1]  Outside the bowl, ocean conditions are attractive to surfers near a large offshore rock pinnacle named Gull Rock, located about 1\xe2\x81\x842 mile (800\xc2\xa0m) west-northwest of Devils Punch Bowl, which funnels and concentrates waves easily seen from the park.  There are at least seventeen large rocks, part of Oregon Islands National Wildlife Refuge, which provide interesting wave viewing, and attract and provide a home for wildlife.'

name: Ellmaker State Wayside
description: b'Ellmaker State Wayside is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.  It is located on U.S. Route 20 approximately 1 mile (1.6\xc2\xa0km) north of the community of Burnt Woods.'

name: Fogarty Creek State Recreation Area
description: b'Fogarty Creek State Recreation Area is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Gleneden Beach State Recreation Site
description: b'Gleneden Beach State Recreation Site is a state park administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department in the U.S. state of Oregon. Located along the Pacific Ocean 7 miles (11\xc2\xa0km) south of  Lincoln City, it offers public beach access, picnicking, and fishing in a setting of shore pines, sandstone bluffs, and sand. The park is fee-free.[2]'

name: H. B. Van Duzer Forest State Scenic Corridor
description: b'H. B. Van Duzer Forest State Scenic Corridor is a 12-mile (19\xc2\xa0km) scenic driving route along Route 18 in Lincoln, Tillamook, and Polk counties in the U.S. state of Oregon that passes through a forested corridor. The Van Duzer Corridor stretches from northwestern Polk County to Lincoln City, passing through the Northern Oregon Coast Range.'

name: Neskowin Beach State Recreation Site
description: b'Neskowin Beach State Recreation Site is a state park in Tillamook County, Oregon, United States, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Otter Crest State Scenic Viewpoint
description: b'Otter Crest State Scenic Viewpoint is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.  Going north on State Highway 101 the turnoff to the left comes up quickly and is easy to miss in the dense foliage.  Taking it ones gets a view of Cape Foulweather.'

name: Roads End State Recreation Site
description: b'Roads End State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Beverly Beach State Park
description: b'Beverly Beach State Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon located 5 miles (8.0\xc2\xa0km) north of Newport. It is a full R.V. hookup camping area with showers, bathrooms, beach access, and a meeting hall where evening interpretive programs take place. The park also has tent areas, as well as yurts for rent. The yurts have a heater, beds, table, and a porch.'

name: Collier Memorial State Park
description: b'Collier Memorial State Park is a state park in southern Oregon. The park is operated and maintained by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. It is located on U.S. Highway 97, approximately 30 miles (48\xc2\xa0km) north of Klamath Falls and 105 miles (169\xc2\xa0km) south of Bend. The park covers 146 acres (59\xc2\xa0ha) along the Williamson River.'

name: Jackson F. Kimball State Recreation Site
description: b'Jackson F. Kimball State Recreation Site is a state park in southern Oregon. The park is operated and maintained by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, and is located approximately 20 miles (32\xc2\xa0km) southeast of Crater Lake National Park and 3 miles (4.8\xc2\xa0km) north of Fort Klamath. The park was established in 1955, and covers 19 acres (7.7\xc2\xa0ha) including the headwaters of the Wood River.'

name: OC&E Woods Line State Trail
description: b"The OC&E Woods Line State Trail is a rail trail in Klamath and Lake counties in the U.S. state of Oregon. It is Oregon's longest state park. The trail follows the old OC&E (Oregon, California and Eastern) and Weyerhaeuser railroads from Klamath Falls to Thompson Reservoir.  Along its 105-mile (169\xc2\xa0km) length it passes through the communities of Olene, Sprague River, Dairy, Beatty, and Bly."

name: South Jetty (South Beach)
description: b'South Jetty is a state park in Newport, Oregon, U.S.'

name: Blue Mountain Forest State Scenic Corridor
description: b'Blue Mountain Forest State Scenic Corridor is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Battle Mountain Forest State Scenic Corridor
description: b'Battle Mountain Forest State Scenic Corridor is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Sumpter Valley Gold Dredge
description: b'The Sumpter Valley Gold Dredge is a historic gold dredge located in Sumpter, in the U.S. state of Oregon.  Gold was discovered in Sumpter in 1862. Three gold dredges were put into service in the Sumpter Valley district between 1912 and 1934.'

name: Fall Creek State Recreation Site
description: b'Fall Creek State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. The park includes 47 campsites that do not include many luxuries. Each site includes a picnic table and a fire ring. There is also a designated swimming area in the lake that Fall Creek flows into. A dock and boat ramp are on the lake as well.[2]'

name: Lowell State Recreation Site
description: b'Lowell State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Jasper State Recreation Site
description: b'Jasper State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Dexter State Recreation Site
description: b'Dexter State Recreation Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Munson Creek Falls State Natural Site
description: b'Munson Creek Falls State Natural Site is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Willamette Stone
description: b'The Willamette Stone was a small stone obelisk originally installed by the Department of Interior in 1885 in the western hills of Portland, Oregon in the United States to mark the intersection and origin of the Willamette meridian and Willamette baseline. It replaced a cedar stake placed by the Surveyor General of the Oregon Territory in 1851; this stake defined the grid system of sections and townships from which all real property in the states of Oregon and Washington has been measured following the Donation Land Claim Act of 1850. The Willamette meridian runs north\xe2\x80\x93south, and the Willamette baseline runs east\xe2\x80\x93west through the marker.[1]  The easternmost northeast corner of Washington County is sited on the marker.'

name: Umpqua State Scenic Corridor
description: b'Umpqua State Scenic Corridor is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Clay Myers State Natural Area at Whalen Island
description: b'Clay Myers State Natural Area at Whalen Island is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Government Island (Oregon)
description: b'Government Island is a 1,760-acre (710\xc2\xa0ha) island in the Columbia River north of Portland, in Multnomah County, in the U.S. state of Oregon. Though Interstate 205 passes over it on the Glenn L. Jackson Memorial Bridge, access to the island is only by boat. There is a city controlled locked gate in the 205 fence.'

name: Sunset Beach State Recreation Site
description: b'Sunset Beach State Recreation Site is a state park in Clatsop County, Oregon, United States, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.  The park comprises 120 acres (49\xc2\xa0ha) along the Pacific Ocean on the Clatsop Plains.'

name: Depoe Bay Whale Watching Center
description: b'The Depoe Bay Whale Watching Center, also known as the Depoe Bay Ocean Wayside, is an Oregon State Parks-staffed visitor center in Depoe Bay, Oregon, U.S. to help visitors observe whale migration and provide information about whales and other marine mammals, including history, economics, and their environmental and ecological influences. The wayside provides a sheltered platform from which to view the ocean. First established as a wayside parking area on the Oregon Coast Highway in 1930, the wayside building was built in 1956 as a restroom facility for the popular spot.[4] It is located just to the north of the Depoe Bay Bridge, also on the National Register.'

name: Rocky Creek State Scenic Viewpoint
description: b'Rocky Creek State Scenic Viewpoint is a state park in Lincoln County in northwestern Oregon, United States. Administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, the 59-acre (24\xc2\xa0ha) park lies along a bluff between Whale Cove and Rocky Creek. The park extends south along the Otter Crest Loop Road to the Rocky Creek Bridge.[3]'

name: Fort Yamhill
description: b'Fort Yamhill was an American military fortification in the state of Oregon. Built in 1856 in the Oregon Territory, it remained an active post until 1866. The Army outpost was used to provide a presence next to the Grand Ronde Agency Coastal Reservation. Several officers stationed at the United States Army post prior to the American Civil War would later serve as generals in that war.'

name: L. L. "Stub" Stewart State Park
description: b'L. L. "Stub" Stewart Memorial State Park is a 1,654-acre (669\xc2\xa0ha) Oregon state park in Washington County near the community of Buxton. When the park opened in 2007 it was the first new full-service state park in Oregon since 1972.[2] The park includes hiking trails, mountain bike trails, horseback riding, RV and tent campsites, and cabins among other amenities. Located off Oregon Route 47 in the foothills of the Northern Oregon Coast Range, the park connects to the Banks\xe2\x80\x93Vernonia State Trail.'

name: Thompson's Mills State Heritage Site
description: b'Thompson\'s Mills State Heritage Site is a state park near Shedd in Linn County, Oregon, United States, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department. The mill was first built in 1858. It burned down in 1862, but was rebuilt right away and those 12 inch by 12 inch hand hewn beams cut and placed while Lincoln was in office are still visible inside the mill today . A series of dedicated and tenacious owners adapted the mill to changing times turning the flour mill to a feed mill and eventually a hydroelectric plant operating until 2004, making it one of Oregon\'s oldest continuously operating water-powered businesses. Oregon State Parks purchased the property in 2004 and the park was opened to the public in December, 2007. The property was acquired and restored under governor Kulongoski\'s "park-a-year" plan, in which one new state park is to be opened every year. Free guided tours are offered daily allowing visitors to see the water powered turbines and machinery in action. The grounds are being restored to the 1910-1930\'s era with the heirloom orchard, gardens and plantings restored as well as heritage poultry roaming the grounds and original fence lines and paths; all will be open to the public when complete.'

name: Arizona Beach State Recreation Site
description: b'Arizona Beach State Recreation Site is a 68-acre (28\xc2\xa0ha)[2] Oregon state park in Curry County, Oregon, in the United States. The beach is at an average elevation of 7 feet (2\xc2\xa0m).[1] Public recreational facilities at Arizona Beach State Recreation Site include a parking lot for beach access, observation areas for viewing marine mammals and birds and tables for picnicking. The park is open year-round.[3]'

name: Bates State Park
description: b'Bates State Park is a 131-acre (53\xc2\xa0ha) state park in Grant County, Oregon, USA, near Prairie City. The park includes hiking trails, primitive RV and tent campsites, and a day use area for hikers and bicyclists.[1]'

name: Ochoco State Scenic Viewpoint
description: b'Ochoco State Scenic Viewpoint is a state park in the U.S. state of Oregon, administered by the Oregon Parks and Recreation Department.'

name: Dyer State Wayside
description: b'Dyer State Wayside, a rest stop with picnic tables and public toilets, lies about 10 miles (16\xc2\xa0km) south of Condon, along Oregon Route 19. It occupies 0.6 acres (0.24\xc2\xa0ha) in a narrow canyon along a branch of Thirty Mile Creek[2] at the mouth of Ramsey Canyon.[3]'

name: Pete French Round Barn
description: b'The Pete French Round Barn, located near Burns, Oregon, United States, is a round barn listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The late 19th century barn was owned and constructed by cattle rancher Peter French; French trained horses there during the winter. The barn was listed on the National Register on September 10, 1971.'

name: Cottonwood Canyon State Park
description: b'Cottonwood Canyon State Park, established in 2013, is the second largest state park in Oregon, encompassing 8,000 acres (3,200\xc2\xa0ha) on the lower John Day River.[1] The largest is Silver Falls State Park at 9,064 acres (3,668\xc2\xa0ha).[1]'

name: Bear Butte
description: b'Bear Butte is a geological laccolith feature located near Sturgis, South Dakota, United States, that was established as a State Park in 1961. An important landmark and religious site for the Plains Indians tribes long before Europeans reached South Dakota, Bear Butte is called Mat\xc8\x9f\xc3\xb3 Pah\xc3\xa1,[2] or Bear Mountain, by the Lakota, or Sioux. To the Cheyenne, it is known as Noah\xc8\xa7-vose ("giving hill") or N\xc3\xa1hk\xc8\xafhe-vose ("bear hill"),[3] and is the place where Ma\'heo\'o (God) imparted to Sweet Medicine, a Cheyenne prophet, the knowledge from which the Cheyenne derive their religious, political, social, and economic customs.'

name: Beaver Creek Nature Area
description: b'Beaver Creek Nature Area is a nature area in Minnehaha County, South Dakota in the United States. It is located along Beaver Creek, a tributary of  the Big Sioux River just east of Sioux Falls. Birdwatching, fishing, hiking, and snowmobiling are popular activities within this area. Wildlife found in the area include: Bald eagle, White-tailed deer, Coyote, Beaver, and many song birds and waterfowl.[1]'

name: Big Stone Island Nature Area
description: b'Big Stone Island Nature Area is a nature area on Big Stone Island in Big Stone Lake in Roberts County, South Dakota. The island is also known as Kite Island and Big Island and is near the border with Minnesota. Originally the island was a village used by the Plains Indians. During the late 1800s and early 1900s several resorts were located on the island but were abandoned. In the 1940s during World War II the island was used by military aircraft to practice take-offs and landings. The area is only accessible by boat or canoe and today preserves the island for wildlife.[1]'

name: Chief White Crane Recreation Area
description: b'Chief White Crane Recreation Area is a state recreation area in southeastern South Dakota, United States. It is located about 5 miles (8.0\xc2\xa0km) west of Yankton and located on the shores of the Missouri River and Lake Yankton. The recreation area is located about 1.5 miles (2.4\xc2\xa0km) downstream of Gavins Point Dam and Lewis and Clark Lake.[1]'

name: Custer State Park
description: b"Custer State Park is a South Dakota State Park and wildlife reserve in the Black Hills, United States. The park is South Dakota's largest and first state park, named after Lt. Colonel George Armstrong Custer. The park covers an area of over 71,000 acres (287\xc2\xa0km2) of varied terrain including rolling prairie grasslands and rugged mountains.[2]"

name: Fisher Grove State Park
description: b'Fisher Grove State Park is a South Dakota state park in Spink County, South Dakota in the United States. The park is open for year-round recreation including camping, swimming, fishing, hiking and boating.[1] It is 8 miles (13\xc2\xa0km) east of Redfield, South Dakota.'

name: Fort Sisseton
description: b'Fort Sisseton near Britton, South Dakota was established in 1864.  As Fort Sisseton Historic State Park, it was designated as a State Historical Park in 1959.[2]  Fort Sisseton is listed on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places.[1]'

name: Good Earth State Park
description: b"Good Earth State Park is a South Dakota State Park in Lincoln County, South Dakota in the United States along the Big Sioux River.[1]  The park is open for year-round recreation including hiking.[2] The park includes the Blood Run Site, a National Historic Landmark significant for its history as a settlement for thousands of Native Americans.[3] A visitor center includes displays about the site's significance."

name: Hartford Beach State Park
description: b'Hartford Beach State Park is a South Dakota state park on Big Stone Lake in Roberts County, South Dakota in the United States.  The park is open for year-round recreation, including cabins, camping, swimming, fishing, hiking, disc golf and boating.[1]'

name: Lake Herman State Park
description: b'Lake Herman State Park is a South Dakota state park in Lake County, South Dakota in the United States.  The park is open for year-round recreation including camping, swimming, fishing, hiking and boating on the 1,350-acre Lake Herman.[1] There are 72 campsites which feature electric hook-ups and 2 cabins.[2]'

name: Lake Vermillion Recreation Area
description: b'Lake Vermillion Recreation Area is a South Dakota state recreation area in McCook County, South Dakota in the United States. The park is open for year-round recreation including camping, swimming, fishing, hiking and boating on Lake Vermillion.[1]'

name: Newton Hills State Park
description: b'Newton Hills State Park is a South Dakota state park in Lincoln County, South Dakota in the United States.  The park is 1,063 acres (430\xc2\xa0ha) and sits at an elevation of 1,309 feet (399\xc2\xa0m).[1] Newton Hill State Park is open for year-round recreation including camping, swimming, fishing, hiking and boating. It is 12 miles (19\xc2\xa0km) east of Interstate 29 and south of Canton.[2]'

name: Oakwood Lakes State Park
description: b'Oakwood Lakes State Park is a South Dakota state park in Brookings County, South Dakota in the United States.  The park is open for year-round recreation including camping, swimming, fishing, hiking and boating on Johnson Lake and Lake Tetonkaha.[1] There are 136 campsites and 6 cabins.[2]  The visitor center features an archaeology display of items found in the area. Other activities include a boat ramp, canoe and kayak rentals, horse camp sites and cross-country skiing.'

name: Palisades State Park
description: b"Palisades State Park is a state park of South Dakota, USA, featuring cliffs and rock formations eroded out of pink Sioux Quartzite.  The park is located just south of Garretson, 10 miles (16\xc2\xa0km) off Interstate 90.  At only 157 acres (64\xc2\xa0ha), it is South Dakota's second-smallest state park.[1]"

name: Pierson Ranch Recreation Area
description: b'Pierson Ranch Recreation Area is a state recreation area in Yankton County, South Dakota in the United States.  The recreation area is 60 acres (24\xc2\xa0ha) and lies directly below Gavins Point Dam and Lewis and Clark Lake and is adjacent to Lake Yankton. The area is open for year-round recreation including camping, swimming, fishing, hiking and boating. It is 4 miles (6.4\xc2\xa0km) west of Yankton.[1]'

name: Platte Creek Recreation Area
description: b'Platte Creek Recreation Area is a South Dakota state recreation area located on the eastern shore of Lake Francis Case, a Missouri River Reservoir in Gregory County, South Dakota in the United States.  The recreation area is 252 acres (102\xc2\xa0ha). The area is open for year-round recreation including camping, swimming, fishing, hiking and boating.[1]'

name: Randall Creek Recreation Area
description: b'Randall Creek Recreation Area is a South Dakota state recreation area in Gregory County, South Dakota in the United States.  The recreation area is 184 acres (74\xc2\xa0ha) and lies directly below Fort Randall Dam, along the banks of the Missouri River. The area is open for year-round recreation including camping, swimming, fishing, hiking and boating.[1]'

name: Roughlock Falls Nature Area
description: b'Spearfish Canyon Nature Area is a nature area in Lawrence County, South Dakota in the United States.
